    [0] {

          :question_id => 1557945,
              :created => "2026-01-01 08:05:22 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-01 08:05:22 -0800",
              :content => "<p>If he account is IMAP, the only solution is to create the account, not copy it. If it is a POP account, you could first copy the existing mail\\&lt;POP account folder&gt;, set up the POP account on the other computer, and then paste the copied contents into the account folder, overlaying the default contents. Do the paste when thunderbird is NOT running and before you start retrieving new messages.  </p><p>TIP: when copying profiles from one computer to  another, and IF the accounts are IMAP, just exit thunderbird, in imapmail\\&lt;IMAP account folder&gt;, just delete the inbox and other folders, and the profile will be much smaller than 8 gig. Thunderbird will repopulate the message folders. </p>",
              :creator => "davidsk",
              :is_spam => "false",
          :num_helpful => 0,
        :num_unhelpful => 0

              :content => "<p>This forum is not supported by developers, but by peer users like you. We do not make these decisions. In general, Thunderbird does not support or debug addons; that is the developer role. Also, by using the latest release, you are more likely to encounter addon issues, as developers must be continually involved with latest updates. it is routine for users to post that an addon isn't working properly with the latest release. If reliable results from addons is a priority, my personal recommendation is to stick with the ESR release. My opinion - and it's nothing more than that - is that the developer has direct contact with the appropriate persons and could probably work through this issue better. If you believe there is a bug in Thunderbird, you can post it at <a href=\"http://bugzilla.mozilla.org\" rel=\"nofollow\">bugzilla.mozilla.org</a>. </p>",
              :creator => "davidsk",

Technically it isn't entirely correct to refer to AMO for Thunderbird add-ons, as Thunderbird uses it's own add-on store at <a href=\"https://addons.thunderbird.net\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://addons.thunderbird.net</a>. </p><p>The latest version of the 'Allow HTML Temp' add-on is 10.1.1, and it's marked as compatible up to TB v147. <a href=\"https://addons.thunderbird.net/thunderbird/addon/allow-html-temp/\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://addons.thunderbird.net/thunderbird/addon/allow-html-temp/</a> </p><p>That version works just fine here with TB 146.0.1. Why it doesn't work for you I don't know. Perhaps you disabled automatic add-on updates in Thunderbird? </p><p>With the latest version of the add-on you shouldn't need to mess with the max_version option in the manifest.json file.  I'd suggest to remove the messed up version of the add-on in your installation of Thunderbird, restart Thunderbird, and then install the latest version via the Thunderbird Add-on Manager. Also see <a href=\"https://support.mozilla.org/kb/installing-addon-thunderbird\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://support.mozilla.org/kb/installing-addon-thunderbird</a> </p>",
              :creator => "christ1",

              :content => "<p>Thunderbird switched from one release to two earlier this year: a monthly version that would receive latest features, and the ESR version that receives an annual release and support patches through the year. the ESR release is at 140, while monthly is at 146.  If interested in the ESR, this URL may help, although switching to a prior release sometimes creates its own problems:  <a href=\"https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-release\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-release</a>   if addons remain vital to you, and you wish to stay with the monthly release, you may want to change the automatic update to just notify - that is done at settings&gt;general. </p>",

              :content => "<p>General instructions are at <a href=\"https://kb.mozillazine.org/Moving_your_profile_folder_-_Thunderbird\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://kb.mozillazine.org/Moving_your_profile_folder_-_Thunderbird</a>   I encourage that the receiving thunderbird be at least at same release as from the sending computer. I've done this several times and it works The profile manager works well. A modification of the profile manager approach is this:  - exit thunderbird - make a copy of the profile - install thunderbird on linux, start and then exit - copy the windows profile and paste over the top of the active linux profile and you're done. Do this when thunderbird not running.  </p><p>If unsure how to find profile location, these steps work on windows and linux:  - click help&gt;troubleshootinginformation - scroll to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder' - exit thunderbird and you will be in the profile </p>",
              :creator => "davidsk",
              :is_spam => "false",
          :num_helpful => 0,
        :num_unhelpful => 0
    },
    [1] {
                   :id => 1790717,
          :question_id => 1557973,
              :created => "2026-01-01 15:02:25 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-01 15:02:25 -0800",
              :content => "<p>David, thanks so much.  I copied the windows profile directory contents onto  a USB stick ( not a zip file) and then deleted the default profile contents under the folder on my other computer running the Linux Thunderbird, without changing the name of the default directory. Then restarted Thunderbird in Linux and worked like a charm.  Much appreciated for the newbie on day 1 of the Ubuntu Linux training. Lots more learning.  Most grateful for your help.  Richard. </p>",

    [4] {
                   :id => 1791303,
          :question_id => 1558082,
              :created => "2026-01-04 07:41:52 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-04 07:41:52 -0800",
              :content => "<p>On a dell webpage, I've found a video which explains how to restart computer in '<strong>Safe Mode with Networking'</strong> It may be of help. </p><p>Please note: you will need to use an ethernet cable to connect computer to router/hub.  'Safe mode with Networking' does not work if using wifi. </p><p>How to Boot into Safe Mode in Windows 11 or Windows 10  </p> <ul><li> <a href=\"https://www.dell.com/support/kbdoc/en-uk/000124344/how-to-boot-to-safe-mode-in-windows-10\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://www.dell.com/support/kbdoc/en-uk/000124344/how-to-boot-to-safe-mode-in-windows-10</a> </li></ul> <p><br> <strong>re&nbsp;:Thunderbird keeps asking me for my password but it won't accept it. </strong> </p><p>I have a BT mail account. I had a problem after changing my BT password. Originally, I had a password to access the actual account and another password for the email webmail account. Updating them failed. This did not work for email. I had to make sure both the BT account (where you look for bills etc) had to have the same password as the email - webmail account. So, check you have that set up first. </p><p>Then in Thunderbird, make sure both incoming and outgoing have same password as used above. </p> <ul><li> Settings &gt; Privacy &amp; Security </li><li> scroll to Passwords section. </li><li> click on 'Saved Passwords' </li><li> click on 'Show Passwords' </li></ul> <p>You should have two lines - one for incoming and one for outgoing. The 'username' will show your bt email address. If pop then it will start with&nbsp;: mailbox://<a href=\"http://mail.btinternet.com\" rel=\"nofollow\">mail.btinternet.com</a>.... If imap it will start with&nbsp;: imap://<a href=\"http://mail.btinternet.com\" rel=\"nofollow\">mail.btinternet.com</a>.... Outgoing smtp will start with: smtp://<a href=\"http://mail.btinternet.com\" rel=\"nofollow\">mail.btinternet.com</a>.... </p><p>For both incoming and outgoing lines do this: </p> <ul><li> Right click on line and select 'Edit Password' </li><li> Completely clear all content and carefully type in the correct password. </li><li> When you have done both click on 'Close' </li></ul> <p>Please tell me if by any chance you have also selected the option to  'Use a Primary Password' You would only need to use that option if you are A) sharing the computer with someone else and B) they also have access to the same computer User Account and C) you do not want them to have access to see your stored passwords. </p><p>Then Exit Thunderbird. </p><p><strong>re: Anti-Virus software</strong> I would advise that you do not want any Anti-Virus accessing your Thunderbird profile folders. So if profile stuff is here&nbsp;: C://Users/username/Appdata/Roaming/<strong>Thunderbird</strong> In Anti-Virus - Create an exception to not scan that 'Thunderbird' folder. </p><p>AV's have a habit of checking every file that gets opened and scanning stuff. When you download, a file gets opened to write to the file, when you send a file gets opened to save the sent email etc and also there is communication downloading uploading to server.  That can have a performance issue - hence why testing a restart in 'Safe Mode with Networking' to see if it really is interfering. </p><p>So, either create the exception to not scan profile OR do the restart test. </p><p>Please note - if you just stop Malware Bytes then the Windows 11 Anti-Virus will kick in - hence the ideal is to test in 'Safe Mode with Networking'. </p><p>Whilst you are at it ... Firewall - it might be controlled by Windows or by an Anti-virus. Access Firewall and make sure Thunderbird program has been set up as allowed. </p><p>Also check computer for a VPN which may have been enabled by you or by an Anti-Virus product. Switch it off. </p><p>Then restart Thunderbird </p>",
              :creator => "Toad-Hall",
              :is_spam => "false",
          :num_helpful => 0,
        :num_unhelpful => 0
    },

If enabled, you will see images that are linked to your message displayed without further action from you. Keep in mind that this can be dangerous, or at least a security lapse - automatically displayed images can alert the sender that you have opened the email, which you may not want, especially in the case of spammers and scammers. Better to leave the setting turned off and enable it only for sources you trust. </p>",

Too quote you original posting  </p> <blockquote>Unable to send emails on Thunderbird  I've checked my IMAP settings are they are all correct.  </blockquote> <p>The issue here is IMAP is only for incoming mail and I see no mention of any sort of issue with getting mail.               :content => "<p>I have always had Spam Assassin checked in all of my accounts.  Usually, when I right-click a message that I think is spam and select Mark | As Spam, the message goes to my Spam folder, and I will never see another message from that email address in my in-box again.  That behavior has changed recently. I did look for an entry in Tools | Message Filters, but I only saw rules that I manually created there.  They work fine. If you actually read the URL that you noted above, it pretty much says that Thunderbird learns from your actions. Something is broken. </p>",

    [2] {
                   :id => 1791233,
          :question_id => 1558213,
              :created => "2026-01-03 23:17:15 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-03 23:17:15 -0800",
              :content => "<p>No Thunderbird's behavior has not changed.  You have observed something you perceive as changed.  That does not make it a change. </p><p>Here is the source code for the junk filtering <a href=\"https://searchfox.org/comm-central/source/mailnews/extensions/bayesian-spam-filter/nsBayesianFilter.cpp\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://searchfox.org/comm-central/source/mailnews/extensions/bayesian-spam-filter/nsBayesianFilter.cpp</a>   and the header file is <a href=\"https://searchfox.org/comm-central/source/mailnews/extensions/bayesian-spam-filter/nsBayesianFilter.h\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://searchfox.org/comm-central/source/mailnews/extensions/bayesian-spam-filter/nsBayesianFilter.h</a> </p><p>You will find each change marked in the margin with the date and bug that implemented the change. I am not seeing anything there for years. </p><p>What has changed in December or even recently?  My motivation is about nil on this topic so you have a look. </p> <em><p>RadioWhiz <a href=\"#answer-1791213\" rel=\"nofollow\">said</a></p></em> <blockquote> If you actually read the URL that you noted above, it pretty much says that Thunderbird learns from your actions. </blockquote> <p>It does not say the filter has any regard to the sender,  and I can assure you it does not and never has.  You assume learning has something to do with the message sender and it does not.  </p><p>I do not use SpamAssassin,  or I should say my provider does not and it is something that the mail provider supports and runs on the mail server.  Thunderbirds only role in that is to read the header SpamAssassin sets and honor its decision.  Perhaps SpamAssassin is no longer treating those email as spam so Thunderbird is not either or perhaps your mail provider does not actually support SpamAssassin.  Thunderbird will let you set the filter even if it never sees a header to act on.  I can not really comment if you provider uses SpamAssassin as you make no mention of who that is.  But Microsoft, Google Yahoo and GMX do not use SpamAssassin.  So the majority of folk to not have it offering guidance, regardless of their preferences in Thunderbird what mail provider are your accounts hosted with? </p><p>Thunderbird does not use a blacklist,  which is reason why blog post nor the support document on which it is based make no reference to one <a href=\"https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-junk-spam-messages\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-junk-spam-messages</a>  and  <a href=\"https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-junk-spam-messages\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-junk-spam-messages</a> To quote those sources on how to block individual senders </p> <blockquote> Other Ways to Block Unwanted Messages  Thunderbirdâs adaptive junk filter is not an absolute barrier against messages from specific addresses or types of messages. You can use stronger mechanisms to block unwanted messages: Create Filters Manually You can manually:     Block some senders.     Create filters to block messages based on subject or other criteria. </blockquote>",
              :creator => "MattAuSupport",
              :is_spam => "false",
          :num_helpful => 0,
        :num_unhelpful => 0
    },

D, [2026-02-11T23:30:28.204681 #80361] DEBUG -- : q:{:question_id=>"1558221", :original_poster=>"lhmm"}
D, [2026-02-11T23:30:28.205341 #80361] DEBUG -- : matching_answers: [
    [0] {
                   :id => 1791031,
          :question_id => 1558221,
              :created => "2026-01-03 03:27:27 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-03 03:27:27 -0800",
              :content => "<p>Is there a reason why you want to use another program called Mailwasher to scan emails etc&nbsp;? Some people do like it, but I've never needed another program just to sift through emails. Thunderbird does have it's own methods of scannning and sorting mail by training the adaptive spam/junk mail controls and using Message Filters.  New incoming mail can only be scanned if it is still in the 'Inbox' and has not been previously sorted via webmail filters into other folders. </p><p>You cannot change a current Imap account into a Pop account as it's set up is completely different. You can create a new account for same email address and set it up as Pop. </p><p>Some servers will need you to select to allow the Pop download options. This can only be done via the webmail account. So worth checking Pop is enabled/allowed in webmail before you start. </p><p>Pop accounts can only access the server Inbox and download whatever is in that folder. Pop accounts do not synchronise any folder with the server. They can be considered as completely independent of the server as all emails are stored on your computer assuming you download full copies.Obviously, as all incoming new mail will be in the Inbox, Thunderbird's adaptive spam controls would scan all incoming mail.  </p><p>Please note - anything the server filters deems as spam will be put into the server Spam folder and therefore will never be seen by any Pop account.  </p><p>That means anything in the server Inbox as seen in Imap account can easily be downloaded again into Pop account.   Assuming your Imap account has a load of other folders containing emails, this presents a problem. </p><p>Emails in other server folders eg: Sent or anything you created, cannot be seen by Pop account. There are few methods you could use. I've mentioned three below. It really depends upon how many folders and how many emails are involved. If not too many because most are in Inbox, then method 1 may be ok. If a few folders but not loads, then you could try method 2. If you have a ton of emails in loads of folders then it might be a lot quicker to do a manul copy paste of files directly - use method 3. </p><p><strong>1.</strong> Access webmail account and move emails from a folder into the 'Inbox' and then in Thunderbird pop account click on 'Get Messages' to download them. Then you create a new folder in  Pop account and move those emails into the new folder. Repeat for each folder - this is not exactly that quick, but it depends upon how many folders and emails you are talking about. Ideal if not too many. </p><p><strong>2.</strong>  Create suitably named folders in the 'Local Folders' mail account. Make sure you have got full downloaded copies of all emails: Using the 'Menu Bar' toolbar (it's not enabled by default so you might need to enable it) </p> <ul><li> 'File' &gt; 'Offline' &gt; 'Download/sync now' </li><li> Select 'Mail Messages' </li><li> click on 'Select' </li><li> Suggest you also select 'Work offline once download and or synchronisation is complete' </li><li> For the imap account, select all the checkboxes for all the folders where you want to have full downloads of all emails and click on 'OK' </li><li> Then click on 'OK' to start the sync. </li></ul> <p>Once complete, you should be in offline mode so that nothing can interfer with the next process. </p> <ul><li> Highlight batches of emails </li><li> Right click on highlighted emails </li><li> select 'COPY-TO' and choose an appropriate folder in the 'Local Folders' account.  </li><li> Repeat until you have copies of all emails in the Local Folders account. </li></ul> <p>Advise you always use Copy-to just in case something goes wrong - you can easily repeat the action. This means you end up with all your previously sorted emails now stored in 'Local Folders' and fully accessible. Do check you can select randon emails to test you really can read the content. Once complete, you can go back to the 'online' mode. </p><p>Note: you can remain in online mode and still do the 'Copy-to' Local Folders. Please do not use 'Move-to' because that will m ean a delete off server and if something goes wrong in transfer you could lose emails. At least with a 'Copy-to' you can repeat the action. </p><p>The Pop account will still downloaded everything that is in the 'Inbox' and can be used from that moment onwards for all new incoming mail. </p><p>Then, as you now have good copies of all emails in 'Local Folders' and Pop account, you can delete emails from the imap account or directly off the server via webmail account. Finally, remove the Imap account via Account Settings. The reason I say delete old emails off server is because a lot of servers expect pop downloads to not store so mnay emails on server.  Please note: for some servers eg: gmail, they can only delete emails that get put in the server Trash. Pop accounts cannot delete and put into server Trash as they have no access to it. This means periodically, you would need to access webail account and check older emails have been properly deleted and not still stored in eg: 'All Mail'. </p><p><strong>3.</strong>  Make sure you have got full downloaded copies of all emails - see the download/sync now info in <strong>2</strong> above. </p> <ul><li> Exit Thunderbird - very important </li><li> Access Profile folder </li><li> Click on 'Mail' - right click on 'Local Folders' folder and select to open in a new window </li><li> Click on 'ImapMail' folder and select the relevant imap account folder. </li></ul> <p>Now you should see two windows - one has the contents of 'Local Folders' and the other has contents of the imap account. </p> <ul><li> You need to get copies of all mbox files (they have no extension) and any folders with a .sbd extension. </li><li> Paste copies into 'Local Folders' folder - do not overwrite anything just in case you do have emails already stored in Local Folders. </li></ul> <p>Image below as guide. </p><p>Then Start Thunderbird and check the Local Folders account. </p>",
              :creator => "Toad-Hall",
              :is_spam => "false",
          :num_helpful => 0,
        :num_unhelpful => 0
    }
]

D, [2026-02-11T23:30:28.206897 #80361] DEBUG -- : matching_answers: [
    [0] {
                   :id => 1791038,
          :question_id => 1558230,
              :created => "2026-01-03 04:03:13 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-03 04:03:13 -0800",
              :content => "<p>Not all emails will be HTML. If emails were sent only using Plain Text regardless of how they were created, then they can only display as Plain Text. You can check received emails to see if they have both plain text and html in the code. Have you checked this&nbsp;? </p><p>Select email so it displays in the Message Pane. In the Message Header area click on 'More' and select 'View source. The headers are listed first then you may see the following: </p> <ul><li> Content-Type: text/plain; charset=utf-8 </li></ul> <p>Followed by content in plain text below you may also see another section that starts with: </p> <ul><li> Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf-8 </li></ul> <p>Then there will be a load html and content of email. </p><p>For an email which you believe is HTML but displaying as Plain Text - please check the view source to see if it actually contains both plain text and html. </p><p>what are you seeing in the view source? You could upload an image - you do not have to show all the header section - but seeing images of what you see in Message Pane and what you have in View Source would be helpful. </p><p><br> <em>re&nbsp;: reviewed all the settings</em> It's helpful to state settings because I cannot assume anything. </p><p>If you want to create emails in HTML mode: </p> <ul><li> 'Account Settings' &gt; 'Composition &amp; Addressing' for each account </li><li> Select 'Compose messages in HTML format' </li></ul> <p>Then you need to check what settings you are using to send: </p> <ul><li> 'Settings' &gt; 'Composition' </li><li> Ideally select 'Both HTML and Plain Text' </li></ul> <p>(because some servers get twitchy if both options are not in email and might say email is potential spam.) If you select 'Automatic' then if you use HTML but have only composed message with just text and no formatting then it will auto send in plain text.  </p><p>Choose method you wish to use when viewing messages in Message Pane. </p> <ul><li> Using the 'Menu Bar' toolbar </li><li> 'View' &gt; 'Message Body as' &gt; select eg: 'Original HTML' </li></ul> <p>Needless to say, if email was sent only in Plain Text then it will still only display in Plain text. </p><p>I've known some people talk about not seeing html when they were viewing html, but they were actually talking about not seeing certain images etc. They had blank areas or outline empty boxes. </p><p>In that case, it's probably all about Remote Content. Thunderbird by default does not allow the automaticatic display of Remote content. This is for security and privacy reasons.  </p> <ul><li> <a href=\"https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/remote-content-in-messages\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/remote-content-in-messages</a> </li></ul>",

If profile in Linux used a version more recent than 115.18.0 then delete the 'compatibility.ini' file. </p><p>Basically Exit Thunderbird on both computers. Copy all the contents of the profile name folder on Win7 On Linux - locate the default profile, remove all contents and then paste in the copied contents  then delete 'pkcs11.txt' file and  'compatibility.ini' file.               :content => "<p>Additional info on installtion - system info release notes etc for version 115.18.0 </p><p><a href=\"https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/115.18.0esr/releasenotes/\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/115.18.0esr/releasenotes/</a> </p><p>Please read the system requirements for linux as it mentions - Thunderbird will not run at all without the following libraries or packages - so do check the info.  </p><p><a href=\"https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/115.0/system-requirements/\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/115.0/system-requirements/</a> </p><p><br> </p><p>re&nbsp;: I did some research on the dichotomy between the ******.profile and the ******.profile-default folders. </p><p>Windows OS is not the same as Linux OS In Windows OS, you are likely o see this type of contruction for profile </p><p>C://Users/username/Appdata/Roaming/Thunderbird/Profiles/profile name folder </p><p>The profile name folder can look something like this: 'abc456k.default'  OR '6pw23hl.default-release' It does not matter. Open that profile name folder to see a load of folders and files Make sure Thundrebird is not running otherwise this will not work. Copy ALL of the contents of that profile name folder (do not copy the actual profile name folder itself - just it's contents) </p><p>On Linux computer if installing from the download I mentioned Thunderbird profile is here: home/ .thunderbird/profile name folder </p><p>That profile name folder is created by default when you install thunderbird and you get that request to create a mail account. At that point you exit Thunderbird - this is important otherwise it will not work. Then access the ~/.thunderbird folder It will have a 'profile name' folder of similar contruction to what you saw in Windows - just a different number letter etc. Open that profile name folder and delete all the contents, then paste all the copied folders and files into that profile name folder - so the new profile name folder now contains all the old copied profile data. </p><p>Then delete 'pkcs11.txt' file and  'compatibility.ini' file.  Start Thunderbird. </p>",

D, [2026-02-11T23:30:28.230704 #80361] DEBUG -- : matching_answers: [
    [0] {
                   :id => 1791403,
          :question_id => 1558468,
              :created => "2026-01-04 16:31:03 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-04 16:31:03 -0800",
              :content => "<p>Thunderbird is what is called an \"e-mail client\". E-mail clients provide a way to access messages in e-mail accounts that are hosted on a server and to send and retrieve messages through and from those accounts. It does not replace those accounts. There is no such thing (yet) as a Thunderbird e-mail address. You can use Thunderbird in place of whatever you use to <strong>access</strong> your gmail account, but you would still be using your gmail account in Thunderbird. The only way to escape Google completely is to get an e-mail account from someone else, e.g., Microsoft, Yahoo, Apple, Fastmail, or your internet service provider. Then you could use Thunderbird with that account. </p><p>Mozilla is the organization that makes Thunderbird and Firefox. Firefox is a web browser like Chrome and Safari. It is not relevant in a discussion about e-mail. </p>",
              :creator => "mozilla98",
              :is_spam => "false",
          :num_helpful => 0,
        :num_unhelpful => 0
    },
    [1] {

              :content => "<em><p>Rick <a href=\"#answer-1791403\" rel=\"nofollow\">said</a></p></em> <blockquote>Mozilla is the organization that makes Thunderbird and Firefox. Firefox is a web browser like Chrome and Safari. It is not relevant in a discussion about e-mail. </blockquote> <p><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mozilla_Foundation\" rel=\"nofollow\">Mozilla Foundation</a> is the non-profit which has several initiatives and projects, two of which are subsidiaries owned by the Foundation: </p> <ul><li> <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mozilla_Corporation\" rel=\"nofollow\">Mozilla Corporation</a> makes Firefox </li><li> MZLA Technologies makes <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mozilla_Thunderbird\" rel=\"nofollow\">Thunderbird</a> (sometimes referred to as Thunderbird Project) </li></ul> <p>And it gets confusing because a) people think \"Mozilla\" is one organization (it is several) and b) they share some of the same web space at <a href=\"https://www.mozilla.org/\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://www.mozilla.org/</a>, including support at <a href=\"https://support.mozilla.org/\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://support.mozilla.org/</a> </p>",

              :content => "<p>DId you get this resolved? I don't know Zorin, but I'm familiar with Linux Mint. There, I click the file viewer, the click to show hidden folders and the ..thunderbird folder appears. Replacing that with a copied .thunderbird folder works. But, if that doesn't work for you, I suggest this:  - locate the profile location on the drive. Normally, this can be done by clicking help&gt;troubleshooting information, scrolling to 'profile folder', click 'open folder' and then exit thunderbird. that should place you in the profile.  - at this point, open your backup .thunderbird, locate the desired profile folder, open it and copy all contents and paste into the active profile, overlaying the current contents.  - restart thunderbird </p>",

    [ 9] {
                   :id => 1792216,
          :question_id => 1558779,
              :created => "2026-01-07 15:23:57 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-07 15:23:57 -0800",
              :content => "<em><p>johne53 <a href=\"#answer-1791866\" rel=\"nofollow\">said</a></p></em> <blockquote>Many thanks Wayne. That's brought back my Menu bar, so apart from my item #1 (above) it's pretty much working as expected now!  [Edit...] One more question... I've installed Thunderbird onto my G: drive because my main C: drive is getting a bit too full - so where will the sent &amp; received emails get saved? Will they also go to my G: drive or are they always saved on C:&nbsp;? </blockquote> <p>Thunderbird be default places your profile folder on windows in the directory defined by the windows environment variable %appdata%  if you type that in a run box (windowskey+R) or into the location bar of file explorer you will be shown the folder where Thunderbird will default store your data.  Note that %appdata% contains the application data of many applications.  </p><p>Given how intrinsic to storage these environment variables are,  it might be an idea to brush up on what is available in windows and what they define. Knowing these defaults exist will explain most of the mysteries of where Windows puts things and why.  </p><p>See <a href=\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/deployment/usmt/usmt-recognized-environment-variables\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/deployment/usmt/usmt-recognized-environment-variables</a> </p>",
              :creator => "MattAuSupport",
              :is_spam => "false",
          :num_helpful => 0,
        :num_unhelpful => 0

They appear in Thunderbird only because they are still on the server. Delete them from the server, and they will be gone from Thunderbird too. If you really want to transfer messages, create local folders and move your messages to them. </p>",

    [ 5] {
                   :id => 1791941,
          :question_id => 1558852,
              :created => "2026-01-06 14:08:46 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-06 14:08:46 -0800",
              :content => "<p>Once you get the messages showing up in IMAP folders in Thunderbird, if they are not already ââ¦â </p><p>You should back up your profile folder before continuing: <a href=\"https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-export\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-export</a> </p><p>How you move messages depends on how many you have. If you have tens of thousands, then, I'm told, copying them from IMAP folders to local folders could be unreliable. So you want to see if your e-mail service provider offers a way to download your messages directly from the server without having to use another e-mail client. For example, Google has a \"take out\" process and Yahoo has something similar. That kind of process would also be better if you have many tens of folders because using the process described below would be tedious, time-consuming, and perhaps error-prone. </p><p>If you have relatively few messages and folders, you should copy (not move) the messages from IMAP folders to local folders. </p> <ol><li> Create the local folders that you want. Right click on \"local folders\" in the message pane and select \"new folder\". You said that you already know how to do that. Good. </li><li> Select all the messages in a folder that you want to transfer. Control-a (command-a on a Mac) selects all messages in a folder if that folder has the focus. </li><li> Right click on the selected messages, select \"copy to\" and the destination folder. </li><li> Monitor the copying until you are confident that all the messages have been copied. </li><li> Repeat for each IMAP folder. </li><li> Check that the quantity of messages is the same in every pair of source and destination folders. </li><li> Make another back-up copy of your profile folder. </li></ol> <p>You can now delete the IMAP folders. </p><p>Before you leave your ISP, of course, you'll want to preserve all your messages in the special IMAP folders (inbox, sent, etc.) too. Same process. </p>",
              :creator => "mozilla98",
              :is_spam => "false",
          :num_helpful => 0,
        :num_unhelpful => 0

The other is for accounts. The last screen images that you shared are from the Thunderbird level. I was interested in the account level. But it's good that you shared those images because they show one thing that we want to change. Please go back to the general Thunderbird settings by clicking on the three-line button and selecting \"Settings\". On the left, click on \"General\" if it is not already selected. On the right, find \"Account hub\". Uncheck it. </p><p>Now, on the same screen, look at the bottom left. Click on \"Account settings\". Now we're at the account level. On the next screen, you will see a two-pane window. In the left pane are accounts and categories of settings within accounts. On the right are the settings themselves. Note that you have three accounts. Two of them have names that you gave them. The third is called \"Local folders\". In the left pane, under each of the accounts that you named, there is a category of settings called \"Server settings\". </p><p>Locate the first account that you named. Click on \"server settings\" in its block of settings. Take a screen image. Locate the second account that you named. Click on \"server settings\" in its block of settings.               :created => "2026-01-09 12:10:39 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-09 12:10:39 -0800",
              :content => "<p>Here is what I would do to start from scratch and try to get a properly set-up IMAP account. </p> <ol><li> Disable Total Defense and keep it disabled. </li><li> Do not do anything with folders, either in the IMAP account or in local folders until the IMAP account is set up properly. </li><li> Create a new Thunderbird profile (where a user's accounts and messages are stored) and delete the old one. &lt;alt&gt; if needed to show menu &gt; Help &gt; Troubleshooting information &gt; about:profiles. Create a new profile. Re-start Thunderbird. &lt;alt&gt; if needed to show menu &gt; Help &gt; Troubleshooting information &gt; about:profiles &gt; set the new profile as the default and remove the old one. </li><li> Re-start Thunderbird to ensure that the new default profile is being used. </li><li> Create a new account. Let Thunderbird find the settings. Make sure that it's an IMAP account. </li><li> Check the new account. Does it look like my last screen image? Does it have all the IMAP server folders that it should have? Does it have the folders that you created on the server? If not, right click on the account name in the folder pane, select \"Subscribe\", and check all the folders. Expand the inbox in that list of folders to subscribe to if there are sub-folders of the inbox. Send a test message to yourself. Does it get sent? Received? Saved in the \"Sent\" folder? Are there connection issues? Do all the folders have the messages in them that they have on the server? If there are problems, check the settings that Thunderbird found against the settings that Mediacom says are needed (see attached image). </li><li> If/when everything looks good, copy the user-created folders from the IMAP folders to the local folders. Right click on a folder &gt; Copy et cet. </li></ol> <p>When you have problems, start a new discussion. We will hope that someone who knows something that I don't will respond. </p><p>If this approach does not work, see if Mediacom has an export function that would let you save the messages from the server folders on your computer. You could worry about putting them into an e-mail client later. </p>",

The problem is some file in your Thunderbird profile, probably the file training.dat There is no need to create a new profile, neither. I have seen that you prefer to trust junk mail headers set by SpamAssassin.  </p><p>I advise to make a new depart with adaptive junk mail controls for all your accounts, without using Spamassassin . Before changing your junk settings reset your training data in Settings &gt; Privacy &amp; Security &gt; Junk since your actual junk filter isn't reliable.  Have a look on the screen shots of my actual spam settings per account and my global junk settings in Settings &gt; Privacy &amp; Security &gt; Junk This SUMO article <a href=\"https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-junk-spam-messages\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-junk-spam-messages</a> should give you more insight into junk (spam) filtering in Thunderbird. </p>",

              :content => "<p>If you are very comfortable with windows file explorer, you can simply copy the inbox and sent and other folders to the Mail\\Local Folders in the active profile. A safer way for many is this:  </p> <ol><li> install the addon, importexporttools NG </li><li> highlight Local Folders </li><li> rightclick and select the importexport option to import mbox  </li><li> now, select one of the desired folders you copied from the other profile  </li><li> repeat for remaining folders  </li></ol> <p>You can merge to another folder by highlighting all messages in the folder, rightclick and select COPY to (not MOVE)   </p><p>Alternate approach for merging:  </p> <ol><li> With thunderbird accessing old profile (and with the importexporttool installed) </li><li> highlight folder to be merged into another profile  </li><li> rightclick and select the importexport option to export EML files  </li><li> then, highlight the existing folder to  which you want to merge in the EML files  </li><li> rightclick and select the importexport option to import EML </li></ol>",

              :created => "2026-01-08 17:32:30 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-08 17:32:30 -0800",
              :content => "<p>There is a standard block of text approved for use when folks jump in on someone elses support topics.  It goes. \"If the above information does not resolve your issue, you should consider <a href=\"/questions/new\" rel=\"nofollow\">creating a new thread</a> with specific details about your issue.\"  you might consider it rude,  but it is an integral part of the way these forums are structured. </p><p>The <a href=\"https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/mozilla-support-rules-guidelines\" rel=\"nofollow\">rules and guidelines</a> state.   </p> <blockquote> Do not re-use existing threads started by others, even if they are seemingly on the same subject. Ask a new question instead.  </blockquote> <blockquote> Asked for password to send message from Yahoo account,,, but do not acept the password </blockquote> <p>That usually means you are using the wrong server settings.  Yahoo uses oAuth2 authentication for both incoming and outgoing mail.  Those requests to authenticate using oAuth2 are mostly full webpage requests,  not the more traditional tiny password requests dialogs which I feel you are probably referring to, although I am left guessing as you do not describe what you do or what the request looks like.  I have even seen loads of people in these forums lamenting these oAuth  \"popups\" and asking how to stop them,  apparently unaware they are even a password request.  Of course Yahoo do not help the cause by using a link that does not contain yahoo in it so folks think is is a scam.  But they are the ones choosing to use Yahoo. </p><p>This topic <a href=\"https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1539853\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1539853</a> has a link to what a yahoo oAuth2 signin page looks like.  Is that what you are getting?  If not your settings are to say the least most suspect.  </p><p>If it looks like the one at 5 in this <a href=\"https://portal.webclick.com.au/index.php?rp=/knowledgebase/143/08.-How-to-change-your-email-password-in-ThunderBird.html\" rel=\"nofollow\">link </a>your settings are certainly wrong. </p>",

I will assume you use Windows and my suggestions follow that assumption. </p> <ol><li> enter %appdata% in search box in task bar and press enter </li><li> that should open file explorer at appdata\\roaming  </li><li> locate the thunderbird folder and COPY it to somewhere else (this shouldn't be needed, but just being safe)  </li><li> download thunderbird from <a href=\"http://thunderbird.net\" rel=\"nofollow\">thunderbird.net</a>, preferably the same release you were using (either the ESR or Monthly release) and install </li><li> start thunderbird and it should open to the proper profile  </li></ol> <p>This assumes that the profile itself was not corrupted.               :updated => "2026-01-12 01:35:18 -0800",
              :content => "<p>Dear David, </p><p>Thank you very much for your help. I have found the solution to my problem. My Local Folders were not stored in the Profile, but in a different folder, as shown in the screenshot \"Print Screen_Solution\". Right-clicking on Local Folders/Settings displays the path. After a recent Windows update, for some unknown reason, my original folders were rearranged, and I lost the path to my old emails. The Windows \"search\" option helped me find my old \"Local Folders\", and I was able to copy them back to the correct location. </p><p>It seems simple now, but it took me a few days to figure out what had happened. I hope this post might save someone else some time. </p><p>Kind regards,  Jasmina </p>",

Initiating a block from a client is possible when the same firm controls both the server and the client, e.g., Microsoft with Outlook. Thunderbird cannot block. It can only filter. You probably have options at the server for blocking. I block many senders at the server. Blocking and filtering at the server is better if you access mail from more than one client or device. </p><p>How does your screen image relate to your inquiry? </p>",

Nonetheless, I think there should be another way to actually block received emails more easily than creating a lot of filters. It would seem that a default filter could be applied to an email which is received by a Thunderbird user by some mechanism that each time a new spam email is received, the TBird user could click on that email, and it would simply add that email address to the spam/block list. After the first application to that received address by the User click, the email address would be filtered thereafter without having to be manually clicked by the TBird user. I am not a programmer, but I would strongly expect that this mechanism approach could be created. That will filter messages, not block the sender. </p><p>Look above for the screen image that you must have posted. </p><p>Yes, I understand that you are using Firefox. There are two links to the discussion in each notification message. There's no need to use private messages. </p><p>As I said, for \"automatic blocking\", you will need to use webmail or an e-mail client from a firm that controls server and client, e.g., Microsoft.               :content => "<p>Mary, I do feel your pain. Honest, I do. You have mentioned previously the task of reentering contacts. I respect that. BUT, all of your addresses are in two simple files: abook.sqlite and history.sqlite. You RARELY need to reinstall thunderbird, but my inference is that you do. AND, regardless of whether you do, here are some tips to save your addressbook: </p> <ol><li> click help&gt;troubleshootinginformation </li><li> scroll to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder'  </li><li> exit thunderbird </li><li> select the abook.sqlite and history.sqlite and COPY them to some other place outside of the profile. You may see other files, such as abook-1.sqlite or similar. IGNORE them: just copy the two I mentioned. </li></ol> <p>Now, if you ever reinstall thunderbird and need to repopulate your addressbook, just do this: </p> <ol><li> click tools&gt;import&gt;import from a file </li><li> follow the menus for addressbook </li><li> at the one that mentions format, including sqlite, click that and select your exported abook.sqlite file  </li><li> repeat the above to import your history.sqlite file </li><li> now, restart thunderbird and all of your contacts will be there. </li></ol>",
              :creator => "davidsk",
              :is_spam => "false",
          :num_helpful => 0,

They would therefore be gone from both your local folder and the server. I am not going to test this. </p><p>It should be relatively easy to check your AV for evidence of a virus detection and quarantine. If you're using Windows' built-in Defender, here's how: </p> <hr> <p>Restore quarantined files in Microsoft Defender Antivirus </p><p>Depending on how Microsoft Defender Antivirus is configured, it quarantines suspicious files. If you're certain a quarantined file isn't a threat, you can restore it on your Windows device. </p><p>Using the Windows Security app </p> <ol><li> 1. On your Windows device, open Windows Security. </li></ol> <ol><li> 2. Select Virus &amp; threat protection and then, under Current threats, select Protection history. </li></ol> <ol><li> 3. If you have a list of items, you can filter on Quarantined Items. </li></ol> <ol><li> 4. Select an item you want to keep, and choose an action, such as Restore. </li></ol>",

If my av quarantined it would it be that even in the providers' webmail interface they wouldn't show either? thanks </blockquote> <p>AV's have no idea that an mbox text file can contain more than one email. If you allow AV to auto fix then there is a high risk of losing emails. It's advisable that you access AV and set up an exclusion to not scan your 'Thunderbird' profile folders. Assuming you have them in the default location... eg: C://Users/username/Appdata/Roaming/<strong>Thunderbird</strong> </p><p>Imap accounts synchronise with server, so if your imap folder is empty then it would delete off the server. In other words the webmail account would not display those emails as they do not exist. </p><p>If you cannot rescue from AV: In that situation you would need to use a backup and import the file into the 'Local Folders' account. </p>",

'Delete' is an option you can add to the 'Unified Toolbar'. Please confirm you are talking about the Unified toolbar. </p><p>Other methods of deleting: </p> <ul><li> Select/open message so you can see it in the Message Pane. Click on the 'Delete' button which is auto available in the Message Header area. </li><li> Right click on email in Message List and click on the Delete/Trash icon top right. </li><li> Enable the column header called 'Delete' - it puts a trash bin icon on each email line - click on it to delete email. </li><li> Select email in Message List - press the keyboard 'del' key </li></ul> <p><br> <strong>Q: </strong>What version of thunderbird are you currently using&nbsp;? <strong>Q: </strong>How many accounts? Set up Thunderbird program as 'allowed' so nothing gets blocked. </p> <ul><li> Confirm Thunderbird is set up as allowed program. </li></ul> <p><strong>Anti-Virus:</strong> Access AV and set up to exclude scanning of your Thunderbird profile folder. If you installed Thunderbird from the official website: <a href=\"https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/</a> Then profile will be here - this is the 'Thunderbird' folder you need to exclude. C:/Users/username/Appdata/Roaming/<strong>Thunderbird</strong> </p> <ul><li> Confirm you have set up to exclude scanning of profile. </li></ul> <p><strong>VPN:</strong> Check computer for a VPN. Some Anti-Virus products now offer a VPN and I have come across some peopl who did not realise one had been enabled. Switch off VPN (or create  split tunnelling and set it up for Thunderbird to use).  Gmail does not like VPN as it atempts to hide your IP address, so gmail decides you might be hacker so it auto blocks access. </p> <ul><li> Confirm VPN is switched off </li></ul> <ul><li> What OS are you using&nbsp;? </li><li> What version of Thunderbird are you using? </li><li> Where did you get the installation download from - Sna, Flatpak. Windows App Store or the official website? </li><li> What Anti-Virus are you using&nbsp;? </li></ul>",

Thunderbird shouldn't care about https cert. The second server has Digicert for https and Let's Encrypt for smtps and imaps, and Thunderbird works. Clicking View certificate for this server shows webserver cert from DigiCert. Thunderbird shouldn't care about https cert. You can run this command for both smtp servers  openssl s_client -starttls smtp -connect <a href=\"http://mail.festa.bg:2525\" rel=\"nofollow\">mail.festa.bg:2525</a> </p><p>and see the output: Connecting to 83.228.123.229 CONNECTED(00000003) depth=2 C=US, O=Internet Security Research Group, CN=ISRG Root X1 verify return:1 depth=1 C=US, O=Let's Encrypt, CN=R12 verify return:1 depth=0 CN=<a href=\"http://mail.festa.bg\" rel=\"nofollow\">mail.festa.bg</a> verify return:1 --- Certificate chain </p><pre>0 s:CN=<a href=\"http://mail.festa.bg\" rel=\"nofollow\">mail.festa.bg</a>   i:C=US, O=Let's Encrypt, CN=R12 </pre> <p>..... ..... SSL handshake has read 3305 bytes and written 1922 bytes Verification: OK .... .... </p><pre>   Verify return code: 0 (ok)    Extended master secret: no </pre>",
          :creator => "laskov548",
          :is_spam => "false",
      :num_helpful => 0,
    :num_unhelpful => 0

Is that right? </p><p>is there way to take a completely different tactic, and download all my messages, then somehow sever that connection to gmail (thus preserving all messages), then set up a second T-Bird instance of the same gmail account to use to delete messages/view any new messages from that point going forward? </p><p>Has anyone found a good method (perhaps with a different client?) to do what I'm trying to do? (ie - download all messages, then delete most from server but keep all messages locally, thus vastly reducing the amount of data on the gmail server? </p>",
              :creator => "operaflute",
              :is_spam => "false",
          :num_helpful => 0,
        :num_unhelpful => 0
    },
    [5] {
                   :id => 1796242,
          :question_id => 1560065,
              :created => "2026-01-25 13:28:21 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-25 14:53:02 -0800",
              :content => "<p>Let me encourage you to do what I did (since I didn't keep notes of where I found what information it would be difficult for me to generate a list of links) and search this forum / read knowledgebase articles. I used a variety of search terms, but found enough information to make progress. </p><p>The general process I followed: (these steps are [mostly] all on gmail) (general process - not detailed step by step instructions) - Make sure that special gmail folders are not being synchronized- All Mail especially, then Purchases, Social, Updates, and etc. (These seem to be additional gmail labels, and would result in Tbird downloading them multiple times.) </p><pre>-- Gmail | Settings | Labels | Show in IMAP -- Thunderbird | Account Settings | Synchronization &amp; Storage --- CHECK Keep messages in all folders on this computer --- Advanced ... Tick or Clear each folder </pre> <p>- (I downloaded thousands of duplicates before I learned what was happening.) - Manually, on Gmail, verify that ALL messages are in some folder. That is, no unlabeled messages. This was a bit time consuming, because I didn't realize all the ways gmail was doing things under the covers that were breaking what I was trying to do. For instance: the search command [ has:nouserlabels ] was failing because of messages that gmail added special labels to. </p><p>Also, in conversation view (which I use), a labelled thread can have unlabelled messages. The simplest way I found to fix this was to create a dummy label (I used ,aaa) then: 1. select ALL messages in one label (myLabel) and add label ,aaa 2. select ALL messages in ,aaa and under the Labels button, CLEAR the ,aaa checkbox and SET the tri-state checkbox for (myLabel). This will add the label to any unlabeled messages. 3. Repeat for all your labels. </p><p>I ran into trouble because I got impatient and didn't wait for gmail to finish executing the command before starting the next step. With tens of thousands of messages in some labels the process took some time. </p><p>Because I'm not syncing All Mail it's necessary to assign a label to every message that I want to preserve. For has:nouserlabels to correctly find all the messages I wanted, I had to remove all the special gmail labels. (If you organize your mail by folders (gmail labels) All Mail will be everything in one big pile - no labels.) </p><p>4. Make certain that Tbird has downloaded ALL your messages, not just headings. </p><p>5. Close Tbird. Using your OS file manager, COPY (don't move) the <a href=\"http://imap.gmail.com\" rel=\"nofollow\">imap.gmail.com</a> [ default name for only one gmail account ] folder from Your profile's ImapMail folder to your profile's Mail/Local Folders folder. When you re-start Tbird it will find your duplicated structure under Local Folders. </p><p>6. After verifying that everything is in your local folders, you can use either Tbird or gmail to delete whatever you want. </p><p>Note: Even after compacting all folders, the IMAP created mbox files can be dramatically larger than a new mbox folder that you copy messages into. For instance: using ImportExportTools NG Search and Export Messages to export all messages from a large IMAP mbox to a new mbox file I saw a compacted mbox drop from 2.6GB to 1.3GB. I'm still in the process of verifying, but it appears that all the messages and attachments are in the copy. </p><p>So - moving messages from gmail (any IMAP provider, actually) to local storage is possible.  Is there a magic tool available? Not that I have found. </p><p>The time consuming piece for me was learning all the ways I didn't fully understand what gmail and Tbird were doing. Once Tbird had fully downloaded all the messages, creating the local copies was fast - simply an OS file manager copy. [ Shrinking the final mbox sizes adds time but is an optional step. As far as I know, the only tradeoff is disk storage space (vs) the time to export messages one folder at a time. ] </p><p>Now, the housekeeping for freeing up space on gmail --- I used the gmail web interface; I believe using Tbird's search and selection and bulk deletion would have worked as well. Which way has more (network traffic) overhead? I have no idea. So: use the tools (gmail or Tbird) that are most comfortable for you. </p><p>(It took me about 2 1/2 days to figure this out and transfer something like 80,000 messages.) </p>",
              :creator => "clifmks",
              :is_spam => "false",
          :num_helpful => 0,
        :num_unhelpful => 0
    }
]

You might need to log out and back on, though I didn't need to. </p><p>Thunderbird has been acting like the default email program in all aspects that I noticed, but the option was unchecked. Maybe a Windows update did that? </p>",

(That said, I'm not clear that the search function in the Message Filters window searches anything other than the names of the filters...) </p><p><br> I just examined the Filter log, which spans 6/9/25 through today, 1/16/26. The results show that: â¢ \"Filter*BS\" ran 41 times between 6/16/25 and 10/8/25 I identified enough incorrectly filed messages in Folder BS during that time period to know that I would have been so frustrated with the problem that I apparently deleted that filter and created a new version, with slightly different actions required (no tagging or priority change, just moving the message to Folder BS). â¢ \"Filter BS\" ran 38 times between 10/17/25 and 11/14/25 Once again, I identified enough incorrectly filed messages in Folder BS during that time period to know that I still hadn't solved the problem by deleting and replacing the filter. And once again, I deleted the filter in frustration, and did not replace it. â¢ Entries including the path to Folder BS appear only 79 times between 6/16/25 and 11/14/25, but there are more than 171 messages in Folder BS between those dates - about double what should be there. â¢ Messages inappropriately filed in Folder BS were received as recently as yesterday, despite the continuing fact that There. Is. No. Filter. Set. To. Perform. That. Move. </p><p>I hope that provides some clarity... many thanks for any thoughts you can offer. </p><p>John </p>",

              :content => "<p>Hi Jesper, </p><p>The error was trying to re-use the previous account and just changing some settings. One has to add the new account, transfer messages from the old account either to local folders or the new account, and then disable or delete the old account. </p><p>The new account seems to be an IMAP account. Is it? IMAP synchronizes folders with the server. When you had your inbox and other folders access the new account, those folders were synchronized with the new account. </p><p>But I do not understand why you can find messages from the old account by searching for them or why the names of all the folders are preserved in the folderTree.json file. So my diagnosis could be wrong. </p><p>I believe that you have two options: </p> <ol><li> Re-connect to the old account if you still can, and start this process over. </li><li> Restore from a back-up. </li></ol> <p>Maybe a third option: if your old account was a POP account, I understand that those messages are still on your local drive.               :content => "<p>If Eclipse is shutting down, I expect anyone attempting to send you an email there will have it rejected/returned because Eclipse won't be there to redirect - and that only works when an email provider has that feature. Your survival strategy needs to be sending emails to everyone you care about with the new email address. That's the best you can do. As far as transferring the messages, That's probably best done by you.If volume is small, you may be able to simply highlight the account folders, rightclick and select 'COPY to' the gmail account. (NEVER use move for IMAP to IMAP.)  A safe way is to use file&gt;offline&gt;download to ensure you capture all messages, use the addon, importexporttools NG to highlight folder, righclick, export to mbox file, and then highlight Local Folders, rightclick and use the importexportoption to import mbox. That gets the messages safely to your PC, Check that you have all the content, not just headers. Now, you can highlight the local messages, select COPY to ' the gmail folders. If there are thousands of messages, I suggest using a manual filter to regulate the transfer. </p>",

              :content => "<p>You seem to have an IMAP account. IMAP synchronizes folders between the server and the e-mail client. When you make a change on a folder, messages will be uploaded and downloaded. If you want messages to be stored only locally, you must put them in local folders. Are you using local folders? </p><p>You could go off line completely, but the folders would be synchronized the next time that you went on line. </p><p>Is this a gmail account? Are you working with the allmail folder? That would explain some or all of what you are seeing in message counts. </p>",

It sits on your IP address, and it uses the server setup that you provide it. It has no IP address of its own. You might try sending a simple, plain text message, no signature, no graphics, and see if that gets through. For example, your email may have a signature that links to another site. </p>",

              :content => "<p>I guess the move is still happening in the background and consuming all the available connection, so no new mail is coming in. </p><p>Each of those message will have to be uploaded to the internet,  so you may find if it was a lot of messages, or they were very large that it might take more than one day.  The upload bandwidth available is also a factor.  Usually that is about 10% of the advertised download speed for consumer grade internet connections. (it is one of the limits providers use to justify changing a lot more for business class internet) </p><p>My recommendation is start Thunderbird without your antivirus product scanning emails as that may well have a significant impact on the success or failure of the activity. </p>",

But now that you've pointed this out, it makes a lot of sense to be aware of the difference.  So I think you're saying that if I had simply moved all messages to a Local Folder, I would still have all of the messages, but Thunderbird would not have to maintain and copy each message from one location on the server to another.  They would all just go to a location on my computer.  Is this right? </p><p>And how will I know if/when Thunderbird is done?  Right now, I can't see any apparent difference in Thunderbird.  How can I tell if Thunderbird is just never going to come back?? </p>",

    [4] {
                   :id => 1795401,
          :question_id => 1560385,
              :created => "2026-01-21 17:55:23 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-21 17:55:23 -0800",
              :content => "<em><p>jkerman <a href=\"#answer-1795398\" rel=\"nofollow\">said</a></p></em> <blockquote>Rick --  Thanks for that tip.  I've never really considered the difference between \"Local Folders\" and the others.  But now that you've pointed this out, it makes a lot of sense to be aware of the difference.  So I think you're saying that if I had simply moved all messages to a Local Folder, I would still have all of the messages, but Thunderbird would not have to maintain and copy each message from one location on the server to another.  They would all just go to a location on my computer.  Is this right?  And how will I know if/when Thunderbird is done?  Right now, I can't see any apparent difference in Thunderbird.  How can I tell if Thunderbird is just never going to come back?? </blockquote> <p>Yes, that is correct. This approach avoids copying or moving messages among server folders, which takes much time and, some people have said, may be prone to errors. </p><p>First, make a back-up copy of your profile. </p><p>Then make sure that all the messages that you want to copy or move are downloaded from the server. I believe that the way to do that is to go into properties of the source folder (right click on the folder and select \"Properties\"), then click on the \"Synchronization\" tab, make sure that the the folder is selected for offline use and press \"download now\". If all your messages were not already on your computer, they should be soon. </p><p>Then create a local folder. </p><p>Now I would go offline so no new messages arrive during this process. Select all the messages in the source folder. Right click on them and select \"copy\" them (not move, in case something goes wrong) to the local folder. They should all be copied fairly quickly. I just copied 2,000 messages in a few seconds. You can tell when the process is done by comparing message counts in the source and destination folders. You can also see entries in the Activity Manager (Tools menu) and maybe progress in the status bar at the bottom of Thunderbird's window. </p><p>Now you can go back online and delete the messages in source folder. If you use the standard delete function, they will still have to be moved to the trash, so there will be a long move between server folders anyway, which you wanted to avoid. But you could use shift-delete to delete them immediately instead of putting them in the trash folder. That should avoid moves between server folders. </p><p>All this is describing what you could have done with your inbox and what you could do with Inbox 2025 now. I am not responding to your initial query. For the problems of Thunderbird crashing and not getting new messages, I would try the standard troubleshooting method: start Windows in safe mode with networking, then start Thunderbird in troubleshooting mode (help menu) and see if the problems persist. If they don't, you can start looking for the culprits. If they do, I probably cannot help anymore. </p>",
              :creator => "mozilla98",
              :is_spam => "false",
          :num_helpful => 0,
        :num_unhelpful => 0
    }
]

You will likely find that the messages not received are in your sent folder. </p>",

Thunderbird, like most/all email clients, is fairly stupid regarding the decision on which email should be sent or not. Thunderbird sends as instructed, leaving it to the network to resolve distribution. You have a case also where all affected users, both sending and receiving, are using the same servers. Some such setups actually bypass the internet when the recipient is on same server. Does that apply to you? Does the server maintain logs of all activity? My belief is that you are looking at the messenger and not at the problem. </p>",

And also whether it's only an issue with B sending. </p><p><strong>Test3:</strong> <strong>D</strong> sends email TO  <strong>A</strong>,<strong>C</strong>, and Cc's <strong>B</strong> Does B get the Cc email&nbsp;? </p><p>That would tell you whether Cc to A is the only problem as cc to D and B are ok or not&nbsp;? If everyone who is Cc'd does not receive Cc then maybe there is an server filter issue or if using an external server or mailbox - a DKIM issue which may allow emails sent using TO but not Cc or Bcc </p><p>ADDITIONAL If D can see a received email which shows A as Cc'd Select email- click on 'More' and select 'View Source' In the headers, is there any mention of a failing DKIM validation? </p>",

                   :id => 1794871,
          :question_id => 1560548,
              :created => "2026-01-19 07:40:12 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-19 07:40:12 -0800",
              :content => "<p>This feature used to be more visible, I think, years ago, but I'm not sure of that. Anyway, in the config editor, check to see if this setting </p><pre> mail.strictly_mime    is set to true. If not click to change to true and then exit. to be sure you changed it successfully, reenter the config editor to verify.  the config editor is at settings&gt;general and is at the very bottom right of screen. That should change all text to unicode.  </pre> <p>I also suggest setting all fonts for consistency. I did this some time ago, but still accurate. go through all steps to ensure that 'latin' and 'other writing systems' are exactly the same.    </p><pre>  <a href=\"https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1462509\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1462509</a> </pre> <p>And, you might be interested in a neat addon, unicodify. I use it to simplify writing to non-English names where umlauts and the like exist. Takes a little customizing and practice. It works by entering a \\ where you want a special character and then toggling to the desired one. It's a little messy at first, but I can't imaging coping without it.  </p><p>And your English is perfect. My French is horrid, all because I failed the subject in 10th grade because I was the only boy in the class and a sophomore, and all the other students were beautiful girls a year older. Grasping French didn't have a chance, as my testosterone was on overdrive at that young age.&nbsp;:)  There, more than you wanted to know... </p>",

Instructions on how to set those variables for each OS are in the \"Environment Variables to set\" section of <a href=\"https://wiki.mozilla.org/MailNews:Logging\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://wiki.mozilla.org/MailNews:Logging</a> . </p><p>As a separate test, if you can, it would help to test a new profile as I mentioned in my previous post. </p>",

    [15] {
                   :id => 1794302,
          :question_id => 1560569,
              :created => "2026-01-16 15:11:34 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-16 15:11:34 -0800",
              :content => "<p>The discrepancy doesn't matter in this case, as it just specifies the log level and there's nothing in level 5 that you wouldn't see in level 4. You can use level 5. Here are instructions on how to do this from the UI: </p><p>1. Go to the hamburger menu in the top right corner of the screen. 2. Choose Settings... 3. In the General section, scroll to the bottom and press the Config Editor... button on the bottom right. 4. Enter \"logging.config.LOG_FILE\". You will see options below the text entry box to create a value as a boolean, number, or string. Select String and press the + button on the right. You'll then see a text box with the ability to enter text. Enter a path to a new file somewhere on your system and press the check mark on the right to save. 5. In the top text box, enter \"logging.ews_xpcom::*\". You will again be presented with the option to create a new value. Choose a number value this time, enter 5 for the value, and press the check mark on the right to save. </p><p>Once you've done that, go back to the main UI and trigger an update (you can do this by pressing the cloud icon with a down arrow in the top left of the folder tree view). After you do that, in the file you entered for the logging.config.LOG_FILE value, you should have lots of content describing what Thunderbird did. Look for errors in that log, or if you want you can email it to me at the email address Wayne mentioned above. </p><p>You can ignore my earlier suggestion to try a fresh profile. That can only be done from the command line. </p>",

              :content => "<p>Your provider only allows email clients to send mail using their servers if it connected to the internet using their service.  This restriction goes back more than 10 years to the hayday of Comcast and Charter and their plans to lock users into their service for phone and desktop.  Spectrum I assume have seen no reason to change the policy.  You might be able to get a VPN to drop you into an IP address supported by SPectrum,  but I do not like your chances. </p><p>They do not place this restriction on the webmail website,  only email clients that use their SMTP server to submit mail. </p><p>Note that the service level agreement included in your spectrum service for email only requires them to make a email service available.  So they save the dollars on proper user support by simply supporting your ability to log into a website, if you can their obligation is met.  Lower support costs for them and the need to hire competent email engineers is lower as email is technically offered, but in reality totally unsupported. </p>",

D, [2026-02-11T23:30:28.457133 #80361] DEBUG -- : matching_answers: [
    [0] {
                   :id => 1794333,
          :question_id => 1560634,
              :created => "2026-01-16 18:08:04 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-16 18:08:04 -0800",
              :content => "<p>I know of two possible causes of this error message. Notice that the error message says two non-specific things. One is that there is the mail server has a problem that has resulted in there actually being insufficient system storage. You can't do anything about this except to contact your email host for confirmation. They have to fix it. </p><p>The other part of the error message, about \"exceeding the allowed number of recipients\" is misleading. Another user in this forum was getting the same error message and discovered that the email host had changed the outgoing server address, but neglected to tell their users. Once the new SMTP address was learned and updated within Thunderbird, all was well again. See this conversation for more context: </p><p><a href=\"https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1560273\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1560273</a> </p><p>So, confirm the server addresses with your email provider, and if you would like help changing them in Thunderbird, let us know. </p>",
              :creator => "rednoise",
              :is_spam => "false",
          :num_helpful => 0,
        :num_unhelpful => 0
    }
]

If I select a cell in a table, right-click, and choose the Select All item in the pop up menu I can then copy and paste the whole table. Slightly weird operability but it works. Strangely, the border colour is not copied across. </blockquote> <p>I went to the trouble of looking at tables copied from Excel at one point as most of the formatting did not arrive in Thunderbird.  I though that was a poor showing of what you see is what you get.  What I found was Excel only put the basic table and data on the clipboard as HTML it put everything on the clipboard in RTF.  Thunderbird defaults to picking plain text or HTML.  I would not put it past Thunderbird to also leave out the styling.   Personally I do not use grids in emails unless I am desperate as they generally present particularly poorly on phone screens.  Lots and lots of left and right scrolling as the screen is so much smaller that the desktop. </p>",

              :content => "<p>Hi </p><p>If you want to use Thunderbird and iCloud together you have to generate an app specific password when you log into the Apple ID website. </p><p>Generate an App-Specific Password Go to <a href=\"http://appleid.apple.com\" rel=\"nofollow\">appleid.apple.com</a> and sign in. Navigate to the Sign-In and Security section. Click on App-Specific Passwords. Select Generate an app-specific password and click Create. Copy password, It looks like xxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxx. </p><p>Open Thunderbird, Account Settings &gt; Account Actions &gt; Add Mail Account. Enter your name and iCloud email address, settings: Incoming Server (IMAP) Server: <a href=\"http://imap.mail.me.com\" rel=\"nofollow\">imap.mail.me.com</a> Port: 993 Connection Security: SSL/TLS Authentication: Normal password Username: Your full email (e.g., username@icloud.com) </p><p>Outgoing Server (SMTP) Server: <a href=\"http://smtp.mail.me.com\" rel=\"nofollow\">smtp.mail.me.com</a> Port: 587 Connection Security: STARTTLS Authentication: Normal password Username: Your full email </p><p>When Thunderbird asks for your password during the setup, paste the App-Specific Password you generated in Step 1, not your regular iCloud password. </p>",

    [2] {
                   :id => 1794627,
          :question_id => 1560773,
              :created => "2026-01-18 04:55:09 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-18 04:55:09 -0800",
              :content => "<p>What is happening it you, like many people, assume the inbox is where pop mail is downloaded from.  <a href=\"https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc1939.txt\" rel=\"nofollow\">The standard </a>actually uses the term maildrop and in most circumstances this is what passes as the inbox as the inbox contains new mail and can be considered synonymous but not always.   Google are offering ALL new  mail to the pop client,  not just the inbox part because all of the new mail has arrived in the maildrop.  </p> <em><p>Groggo <a href=\"#answer-1794576\" rel=\"nofollow\">said</a></p></em> <blockquote>No, what's happening is Gmail is moving the phish to spam, but Tbird is downloading it anyway.  Can you set Tbird to just download what is in the Inbox? </blockquote> <p>No you can not.   POP has no concept of an inbox even, let alone phishing or spam folders  it has a maildrop where all mail received for the address is to be found.  Some providers do not follow the standard and hive off spam from what is offered for download in POP.  I spent time with a very frustrated individual yesterday because their provider did not offer spam so they were forever messing around in webmail to get false positives into their mail client by marking mail as not spam.  For him IMAP was really the only choice as that downloaded all the server side folders,  but it would have been a far superior solution if the provider had just offer the maildrop content without imposing their own non standard take on email.  If you are curious that provider was \"the messaging company\"  they might meet your wants better than Google who are apparently following the standard. </p>",
              :creator => "MattAuSupport",
              :is_spam => "false",
          :num_helpful => 0,
        :num_unhelpful => 0
    },

              :content => "<p>yep the time on an email is set when you compose it,  not when you get it.  There is also no guarantee that your provider accepts it on it's first submission.  Some mail servers with no, or poor, reputations.  They are usually hosted domains and small businesses. Have their email deliberately delayed by the likes of Yahoo, Gmail and Microsoft.  They routinely drop until the server has tried to deliver multiple times of over multiple days to satisfy them the server is legitimate in some way.  Often these servers fail reverse DNS check, or other mail verification because the domain owners are not mail savvy and simply do not configure their new domain correctly to get their mail delivered. </p>",

              :is_spam => "false",

It was incorrect email server protocal. </p><p>CORRECT SETUP IS FOR SPECTRUM IN LOS ANGELES,CA using pop-server: SMTP Server is \"<a href=\"http://mail.twc.com\" rel=\"nofollow\">mail.twc.com</a>\" Port is \"587\" Connection Security is \"None\" Authentication method is \"password transmitted insecurely\" Server Name is \"<a href=\"http://pop-server.ca.rr.com\" rel=\"nofollow\">pop-server.ca.rr.com</a>\" Port is \"110\" User Name is \"each email address's account email\" Use the same \"None\" &amp; \"Insecure password\" for each account Hope this helps someone. </p>",
