If yes&nbsp;: </p> <ul><li> Empty the Junk </li><li> In Inbox - Look for the oldest email that did not get downloaded to Thunderbird.  </li><li> Read it and either delete if not that important or move to another server folder. Get it out of the Inbox. </li><li> Then in Thunderbird try 'Get Messages' to see if moving that email out of inbox gets things moving again. </li></ul>",

              :content => "<p>It's possible you are trying to connect too frequently.  If you are getting auto connects that frequently then is there a reason you keep clicking on 'Get Messages'&nbsp;? I only use 'Get Messages' if I'm expecting something urgently or performing a load of tests. Otherwise my auto check uses anything between 10mins and 30mins. All set for different times with odd minutes as well so the odds on a clash are minimal. </p><p>it's also possible you have an Anti-Virus which keeps scanning any file that gets opened which interupts the connection. You could access your Anti-Virus and set it up to not scan your 'Thunderbird' profile folder.  </p><p>Start by setting the auto check to different times for each account. I'm not sure how many emails you expect to get in less than 10 minutes. Many servers do use Push if IDLE is available, so you would get a notification. eg: 10 mins 13 mins 16 mins 21 mins 29 mins </p>",

D, [2026-02-11T23:30:28.506207 #80361] DEBUG -- : matching_answers: [
    [0] {
                   :id => 1795485,
          :question_id => 1561149,
              :created => "2026-01-22 03:21:14 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-22 03:21:14 -0800",
              :content => "<p>There are many reasons for a fail. That pop up request - where it says  'Enter New Password' - you can only use that option if you have already logged onto the webmail account and updated/modified the current password. </p><p>All Passwords can only be modified via their respective webmail accounts. Then you update the stored password in Thunderbird to match the current password. </p><p><strong>First check that your Firewall is not blocking the Thunderbird program.</strong> <strong>Firewall</strong> It might be controlled by the default supplied by OS OR it might be controlled by an Anti-Virus you installed. </p> <ul><li> Exit Thunderbird. </li><li> Access Firewall </li><li> Make sure the 'Thunderbird' program is set up as allowed. </li></ul> <p>Do not just disable Firewall as that proves nothing is not desirable. </p> <ul><li> Confirm - Thunderbird program is set up as allowed. </li></ul> <p><strong>VPN</strong> Please check your computer to see if a VPN has been enabled. Many Anti-Virus products now offer VPN and in some cases it had been enabled by default. Servers generally do not like VPN because it attempts to hide your IP address and server may block access if it thinks you might be trying to hack the account. Switch off VPN. </p> <ul><li> Confirm you have checked computer for a VPN - also checked your Anti-virus to see if it now offers and has enabled a VPN - VPN is switched off. </li></ul> <p><strong>Now to check the password and third party access settings because comcast uses Xfinity.</strong> </p> <ul><li> Using a browser - logon to your webmail account using your password. </li></ul> <p>Do you get access to the webmail account? If yes, that proves the server is still accepting your password. If not accepting password then there should be 'forgotten password' type of text link which you use nad follow instructions to regain access - then reset password. </p><p>Whilst in the webmail account - check the third party email client settings are enabled. top-right corner, click the Gear icon, then select Settings and Click Security. You need to select the checkbox to 'allow access to my xfinity..... See image below as guide. If enabled already - try the switch it off and then switch it back on to make sure there is no glitch. Strange as it may seem, that unchecking and reselecting the checkbox did work for another person. </p>",

    [0] {
                   :id => 1795492,
          :question_id => 1561154,
              :created => "2026-01-22 03:59:33 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-22 03:59:33 -0800",
              :content => "<p>Need more information. </p><p>What OS are you using? What version of Thunderbird are you using? Where did you get the Thunderbird program? Windows App Store, Snap, Flatpak&nbsp;? Was it downloaded from the official website: <a href=\"https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/</a> Need info because it tell me where the profile is likely to be located. </p><p>Are you talking about an IMAP or Pop mail account&nbsp;? A repair on folder does not delete emails, it repairs the *.msf index file to match what is actually stored in the * mbox file. If emails look like they disappeared then they did not exist, you were just seeing some header information. </p><p>That can occur if an Anti-Virus decides to 'fix' an mbox file - they have no idea that a mbox file can contain more than one email, so if AV nukes the mbox file, the index is not touched, but is out of synch with reality. Gneral advise, do not allow AV's to scan profile files and folders or if you do never allow a fix. </p><p>Also check the following as they can cause a block in accessing server. This needs checking before progressing to other causes. </p><p><strong>Firewall</strong> It might be controlled by the default supplied by OS OR it might be controlled by an Anti-Virus you installed. </p> <ul><li> Exit Thunderbird. </li><li> Access Firewall </li><li> Make sure the 'Thunderbird' program is set up as allowed.  </li></ul> <p>Do not just disable Firewall as that proves nothing is not desirable. </p> <ul><li> Confirm - Thunderbird program is set up as allowed.  </li></ul> <p><strong>VPN</strong> Please check your computer to see if a VPN has been enabled. Many Anti-Virus products now offer VPN and in some cases it had been enabled by default. Servers generally do not like VPN because it attempts to hide your IP address and server may block access if it thinks you might be trying to hack the account. Switch off VPN. </p> <ul><li> Confirm you have checked computer for a VPN - also checked your Anti-virus to see if it now offers and has enabled a VPN - VPN is switched off.  </li></ul> <p><strong>re web host provider,Hostgator,</strong> Have you recently moved to Hostgator&nbsp;? </p><p>Are your emails  being hosted on a Plesk or Windows server? That would effect server settings. </p><p>I presume you can logon to webmail account to see emails on server. So you know password works. Do confirm you can acess the webmail account. </p><p>It would be useful to see what you are currently using for Account SEttings &gt; Server Settings. Easy method - upload an image file which has the username/full email address edited/blanked out. check the username is the full email address. </p><p>Good info at this link: <a href=\"https://www.hostgator.com/help/article/email-connection-settings\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://www.hostgator.com/help/article/email-connection-settings</a> </p>",

D, [2026-02-11T23:30:28.520509 #80361] DEBUG -- : matching_answers: [
    [0] {
                   :id => 1796015,
          :question_id => 1561237,
              :created => "2026-01-24 08:57:38 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-24 08:57:38 -0800",
              :content => "<p><strong>re&nbsp;:so i tried to delete the emails in the wrong folder and it delete all the emails in both folders</strong> </p><p>At least this part is easy to say what happened. So I'm only addressing that part of the issue first. Sorry for the verbose bit that follows&nbsp;:) </p><p>Gmail stores all is emails in the 'All Mail' folder. Gmail understands this is not good for organising or locating emails, so they invented 'Labels'.  That means the 'Label' is like a tag put on the email stored in 'All Mail'. That email can now display a virtual view in any Label (aka folder in Thunderbird) mentioned against that email in 'All Mail'. Although in Thunderbird, it's a real copy because Thunderbird does not use labels like gmail. </p><p>If you delete an email from eg: 'gAMES', you are sending a message to gmail to delete that email. Gmail puts it in server Trash - removes all labels from email and then deletes it from the 'All Mail' folder. That means it's no longer displays in both labels - gAMES and Games. As imap folders synchronise with server folder/label to show what is on server, they simultaneously stop showing same email. The 'All MAil' folder also gets updated to remove the deleted email. So no matter how many copies you have - they all disappear at once because you sent the instruction to delete the email in 'All Mail'. </p><p><strong>So, I hear you ask, how do I only delete an email from gAMES but not from Games&nbsp;?</strong> You have to use the following technique.  </p> <ul><li> select email and hold down 'Shift' key whilst pressing on 'del' key. </li></ul> <p>This has the effect of deleting and by-passing the Trash. Beware there is no 'Undo' for this. What does it do? From your point of view, it removes the email only from the gAMES folder. From Gmail point of view - you sent instruction to remove the 'gAMES' label from that email stored in 'All Mail'. So email still exists in 'All Mail' with the 'Games' label meaning it still displays in the Games label/folder. </p>",
              :creator => "Toad-Hall",
              :is_spam => "false",
          :num_helpful => 0,
        :num_unhelpful => 0
    },
    [1] {
                   :id => 1796018,
          :question_id => 1561237,
              :created => "2026-01-24 09:08:52 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-24 09:08:52 -0800",
              :content => "<p><strong>RE: All Mail</strong> You mention not wanting to get a doubling of size in Thunderbird profile storage when you see any emails in two sets of folders. However, as you also subscribe to see the 'All Mail' folder, that folder contains a copy of every email - incoming and outgoing and archived (stored in All Mail with no labels) - the lot. So your gmail account already has a double of everything.  </p><p>I tend to advise people not to subscribe to the 'All MAil' folder because if you delete anything from that 'All Mail' folder you will be deleting that email from any other folder it resides in. Also, if your Anti-Virus product is allowed to scan folders and it attempts to fix something in that 'All Mail' folder, you stand a good chance of losing all your emails.  It's adviseable to not allow any scanning of your Thunderbird profile because even if it finds something, you do not want it trying to fix anything. AV's have no understanding that one mbox file may contain a lot of emails. </p>",
              :creator => "Toad-Hall",
              :is_spam => "false",
          :num_helpful => 0,
        :num_unhelpful => 0

The one closer to the Inbox is likely to be the correct one. </p><p>Their IMAP locations are different: imap://â¦/Drafts imap://â¦/Draft </p><p>Right click on Folder and select 'Properties' would offer the correct imap folder as used on server. You would need to logon to webmail account to identify which is the server default - is it 'Drafts' I suspect it is or 'Draft'? You should be able to remove/delete the incorrect Draft folder off the server because it's not the default on server. </p><p>In Thunderbird the incorrect Draft folder has been set a 'Draft' flag which means it cannot be deleted. The flag would need to be removed first. But because of the current code it would get reset very quickly. </p><p>Please note, there has been a lot of problems and issues recently because the developers tried to force all default folders to follow a specific set of folder name regardless of what they were called on server and this has caused problems including setting flags and duplicate foldernames. </p><p>Now they have come up with a sort of fix which allows users to switch off the localisation of names and return them to using what the server says to use. I'm not sure what version you are using at the moment but the release version <strong>147.0</strong> has the following: </p> <ul><li> Settings &gt; General </li><li> scroll to very bottom and click on 'Config Editor' button </li><li> It opens in a new tab. </li><li> use the search type: useLoc </li><li> located this preference:  'mail.useLocalizedFolderNames' </li><li> Set pref to <strong>false</strong> </li></ul>",

              :content => "<p>Yahoo usually uses Authentication Method Oauth2. After updating a password in the yahoo webmail account, you would need to access the stored passwords in thunderbird  and remove them. </p> <ul><li> Settings &gt; Privacy &amp; Security'  </li><li> under Passwords section </li><li> click on 'SAved Passwords' </li><li> clickon 'Show Passwords' </li><li> Look for any line that mentions the 'username' = email address of account. </li><li> You may see more than one line for that username. </li><li> Select the lines and click on 'Remove'. </li><li> click on 'Close' </li><li> Exit and restart Thunderbird </li></ul> <p>At the prompt enter the new password. Enter it. You may get a prompt to confirm your password etc and to select to allow Thunderbird access to server. </p><p><em>re&nbsp;: I get the message:-If you still can't sign in try a different device. EG:  </p> <ul><li> a Pop account would have incoming as: mailbox://account.... </li><li> an Imap account would have incoming as: imap://account... </li><li> There will also be an outgoing line as: smtp://account.... </li></ul> <p>For each line you see that is relevant to the account </p> <ul><li> Right click on line and select 'Edit Password' </li><li> Completely clear all the content. </li><li> Carefully type the new password </li><li> When you have done this for all incoming and outgoing lines for the username - click on 'Close' </li></ul> <p>Then Exit Thunderbird and allow a few moments for all background processes to complete. Start Thunderbird. </p>",

              :content => "<p>Before answering the questions below - please check your Firewall is not blocking Thunderbird </p> <ul><li> Exit Thunderbird </li><li> Access Firewall - it might the default used by computer or controlled by an Anti-Virus you installed. </li><li> Set up Thunderbird program as allowed. </li></ul> <p>Please confirm you have done this. </p><p>then Start Thunderbird and see if you get proper synch with server. Can you now read selected emails etc&nbsp;? </p><p>If still a problem.................. You need to supply information because I cannot see your computer. <strong>Q: </strong>What OS are you using? <strong>Q: </strong>What version of Thunderbird are you using? <strong>Q: </strong> Is Thunderbird in the 'Online' state - look bottom left on Status bar - does the icon look like a small circle with radiating semi circles ((o))&nbsp;? If yes then you are online. </p><p><strong>Q: </strong>Are you talking about an IMAP or Pop account? <strong>Q: </strong>Do you see all your accounts and folders in the left Folder Pane&nbsp;? Assuming yes: Please provide answers/comments to all queries. <strong>Q: </strong>When you select 'Inbox' can you see all the emails listed in the 'Message List'&nbsp;? <strong>Q: </strong>Is the 'Message Pane' enabled&nbsp;? If no: Using 'Menu Bar' toolbar OR 'Menu app' icon (3 lines) 'View' &gt; 'Layout' &gt; 'select 'Message Pane' <strong>Q: </strong>If you select an email in the list does it display in Message Pane? <strong>Q: </strong>if you double click on email in list - does it open in a new tab showing content? <strong>Q: </strong>does it show only headers but no email content at all - nothing - blank completely? </p><p><strong>Checking for server connection:</strong> <strong>Q: </strong>When you start up Thunderbird does it connect to server and download messages? <strong>Q: </strong>When you click on 'Get Messages' does it download messages&nbsp;? <strong>Q: </strong>Do you get any error message&nbsp;? If yes, then type it Word for Word verbatim OR upload an image file showing the error. </p><p>Tools &gt; Activity Manager <strong>Q: </strong>Does it mention trying to access server? <strong>Q: </strong>What does it say  for the account name/email address eg: </p> <ul><li> 'Could not connect to server xxxxxxxx. the connection was refused' </li><li> 'No messages to download' </li><li> X messages downloaded </li></ul> <p>For IMAP - Checking delete: <strong>Q: </strong> In Account Settings &gt; Server Settings - 'When I delete a message' - what have you selected&nbsp;? eg 'Move it to this folder and select the server folder 'Trash on account' <strong>Q: </strong>What method do you normally use to delete an email?  eg: right click on email in list and click on the top right trash icon eg: in opened email in Message Header area - click on 'Delete' button </p><p><strong>Q: </strong>What Anti-Virus do you use? <strong>Q: </strong>What is it called eg: Bitdefender I've had one person recently say the Bitdefender AV is stopping the 'Delete' button on 'Unified Toolbar' from working. </p><p>Finally please test in Troubleshooting Mode In Thunderbird </p> <ul><li> Help &gt; TRoubleshoot Mode </li><li> Select 'Restart' and then select 'Continue in Troubleshoot Mode' </li></ul> <p><strong>Q: </strong> Can you select mail and read it and delete it using TRoubleshoot Mode? </p><p>Answer everything and this should give an idea of your setup and what is going on. </p><p>Normally, I would say if you see list of messages but they do not display content when selected, then  Either Message Pane is not enabled  OR index file is not synched up properly with the mbox file that actually holds messages. Usually that can be fixed by right click on folder, select 'Properties' and click on 'Repair Folder', if emails disappear then the emails never existed - but maybe there is more going on, maybe there is no synch to server, maybe the AV had caused a problem by trying to fix an email and ended up nuking the entire mbox file. OR you may have an addon causing a problem OR you may have an Anti-Virus causing a Problem </p>",

              :content => "<p>Sometimes thunderbird creates a new profile on updates. So, my guess is that it is there somewhere.  Try this:  - click help&gt;troubleshootinginformation - scroll to 'profiles' and click 'about:profiles'  - if more that one profile is listed, your addressbook may be there. - click 'open folder' on the suspect profile  - look for a file named 'abook.sqlite' and see if it appears to have been recently updated. Note its location on disk  - in thunderbird, click tools&gt;import&gt;import from a file - follow the addressbook links to the screen with 'sqlite' as an option. click there and then select the 'abook.sqlite file you found - repeat the step to import the related 'history.sqlite' file </p>",

                   :id => 1795163,
          :question_id => 1561328,
              :created => "2026-01-20 16:05:37 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-20 16:05:37 -0800",
              :content => "<p>If a non-gmail account is set to send on a gmail smtp, the From of the non-gmail account is automatically switched to the gmail address, so the recipient sees the message as having been sent from the gmail account.  The remedy is to set the non-gmail account to send on the smtp with non-gmail settings, i.e. the smtp User Name is the non-gmail address. </p><p><a href=\"https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1350593\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1350593</a> </p><p><a href=\"https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1438310\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1438310</a> </p>",

    [0] {

          :question_id => 1561360,
              :created => "2026-01-21 04:22:35 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-21 04:22:35 -0800",
              :content => "<p>Try this:  </p> <ol><li> delete the invalid addresses for a fresh start  </li><li> enter one good email address with fields you normally use into thunderbird' addressbook </li><li> click the three dots to the right of addressbook name and export in csv format. This will be your template </li><li> open that export into a spreadsheet program </li><li> note the top row. this shows the columns as thunderbird expects them to be </li><li> open your exported outlook csv into spreadsheet and adjust columns to match, including the top row.  </li><li> save as csv </li><li> import into thunderbird  </li></ol> <p>Note: the import process does allow for manually adjusting columns during the import, but this is easier. </p>",
              :creator => "davidsk",

D, [2026-02-11T23:30:28.549264 #80361] DEBUG -- : matching_answers: [
    [0] {
                   :id => 1795533,
          :question_id => 1561431,
              :created => "2026-01-22 07:34:23 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-22 07:34:23 -0800",
              :content => "<p><em>Email header populates but message will not - All emails are in Inbox but none populate email message. </em> That means the index file is not properly synched up with whatever exists in mbox file. </p><p>First try this: </p> <ul><li> Right click on Inbox and select 'Properties' </li><li> Click on 'Repair folder' </li><li> Click on 'OK' </li></ul> <p>If everything seems to disappear then emails did not exist in Inbox mbox file, so it cannot display them. That could be because you are not connecting to server. Upon start of Thunderbird, an IMAP account will connect to server and make sure whatever is on server is displayed in the account imap folders. Maybe your Thunderbird is not connecting to server to perform that initial process. </p><p>Please check the following because if they are causing the block then nothing else will work. Exit Thunderbird if it's running. </p><p><strong>Firewall:</strong> Access Firewall - it might be the default on computer or controlled by an Anti-Virus prgram you installed. Set up Thunderbird program as 'allowed' so nothing gets blocked. Maybe the Firewall has not recognised the updated Thunderbird as allowed. If it's already set up, uncheck to block, exit Firewall and then access Firewall again and reset to allow. </p> <ul><li> Confirm Thunderbird is set up as allowed program. </li></ul> <p><strong>VPN:</strong> Check computer for a VPN. Some Anti-Virus products now offer a VPN and I have come across some people who did not realise one had been enabled. Switch off VPN (or create  split tunnelling and set it up for Thunderbird to use).  Gmail does not like VPN as it atempts to hide your IP address, so gmail decides you might be hacker so it auto blocks access. </p> <ul><li> Confirm VPN is switched off </li></ul>",
              :creator => "Toad-Hall",
              :is_spam => "false",
          :num_helpful => 0,
        :num_unhelpful => 0
    }

D, [2026-02-11T23:30:28.550635 #80361] DEBUG -- : matching_answers: [
    [0] {
                   :id => 1795528,
          :question_id => 1561435,
              :created => "2026-01-22 07:12:06 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-22 07:12:28 -0800",
              :content => "<p><em>re&nbsp;: Nobara (Fedora based) - the Google authentication pop up doesn't open</em> </p><p>Check some settings on computer. </p><p><strong>Firewall:</strong> Access Firewall - it might be the default on computer or controlled by an Anti-Virus program you installed. Set up Thunderbird program as 'allowed' so nothing gets blocked. </p> <ul><li> Confirm Thunderbird is set up as allowed program. </li></ul> <p><strong>VPN:</strong> Check computer for a VPN. Some Anti-Virus products now offer a VPN and I have come across some people who did not realise one had been enabled. Switch off VPN (or create  split tunnelling and set it up for Thunderbird to use).  Gmail does not like VPN as it atempts to hide your IP address, so gmail decides you might be hacker so it auto blocks access. </p> <ul><li> Confirm VPN is switched off </li></ul> <p><strong>Localhost:</strong> Do you have anything using the 'localhost'? People who manage websites may typically use eg: Apache Xampp or similar. You need to switch of any program using the localhost whilst setting up gmail. You can enable it again afterwards. I had to switch off Apache Xampp. </p> <ul><li> Confirm nothing is using localhost.  </li></ul> <p><strong>In Thunderbird</strong> </p> <ul><li>     Settings &gt; Privacy &amp; Security </li><li>     Web Content </li><li>     Select 'Accept cookies from sites' </li><li>     Click on 'Exceptions' button </li><li>     Enter this&nbsp;: <a href=\"https://accounts.google.com\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://accounts.google.com</a> </li><li>     Click on 'Allow </li><li>     Click on 'Save Changes'  </li></ul> <ul><li>     Whilst in that area - scroll to Passwords section </li><li>     click on 'Saved Passwords' </li><li>     If you see any mention of the account username email address you are trying to set up - select the relevant lines and click on 'Remove' </li><li>     Click on Close  </li></ul> <p>I would switch off the following as it's still experimental. </p> <ul><li>     Settings &gt; General </li><li>     Account Hub </li><li>     uncheck this checkbox: 'Create accounts in the new Account Hub'  </li></ul> <p>Then create the mail account </p> <ul><li>     Menu app &gt; New Account &gt; Email </li><li>     Enter name </li><li>     Enter gmail email address </li><li>     Enter password </li><li>     Select checkbox to remember password. </li><li>     Click on 'Continue'  </li></ul> <p>Thunderbird by default will look for the IMAP server settings. They should be: </p> <ul><li>     Server name: <a href=\"http://imap.gmail.com\" rel=\"nofollow\">imap.gmail.com</a> </li><li>     Port: 993 </li><li>     Connection Security: SSL/TLS </li><li>     Authentication Method: OAuth2 </li><li>     Username = full gmail email address </li><li>     Password is the same one you use to access webmail  </li></ul> <p>Outgoing SMTP: </p> <ul><li>     Server name: <a href=\"http://smtp.gmail.com\" rel=\"nofollow\">smtp.gmail.com</a> </li><li>     Port: 465 </li><li>     Connection Security: SSL/TLS </li><li>     Authentication Method: OAuth2 </li><li>     Username = full gmail email address </li><li>     Password is the same one you use to access webmail  </li></ul> <p>Assuming all is ok click on 'Done' </p><p>You should then get the gmail pop up browser type window. It will ask you to confirm you really are you and the then askif you want to allow Thunderbird access to server. </p><p>Then an OAuth token gets created and stored in the same place as all other passwords. </p>",
              :creator => "Toad-Hall",
              :is_spam => "false",
          :num_helpful => 0,
        :num_unhelpful => 0

              :content => "<p>If this is to restore to thunderbird, here are the steps: </p><p>For backup:  </p> <ol><li>    ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine </li><li>   enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key </li><li>    this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\\roaming folder </li><li>   highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media </li></ol> <p>To restore, do this:  </p> <ol><li>    ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer, started once and NOT running </li><li>    enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key </li><li>    you should be in Appdata\\roaming folder , copy&amp;paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it </li></ol> <pre>#   start thunderbird and all should be there  </pre> <p>The above steps export all accounts, all messages, all settings, and all contacts. </p>",

D, [2026-02-11T23:30:28.566068 #80361] DEBUG -- : matching_answers: [
    [ 0] {
                   :id => 1795384,
          :question_id => 1561552,
              :created => "2026-01-21 16:32:42 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-21 16:32:42 -0800",
              :content => "<em><p>Ruth Nicholls <a href=\"#question-1561552\" rel=\"nofollow\">said</a></p></em> <blockquote>Is it possible to copy just the Mail folder from a Thunderbird Profile backup in Time Machine on Mac?  </blockquote> <p>No it is not.  The folders of mail are associated with account numbers in your preferences so a plain copy it not the answer.  Generally Time Machine is not the answer. </p> <blockquote> I have deleted an email account from Thunderbird and I did not tick Delete Data so the emails are still there in my Profile but they no longer show up in the tree in Thunderbird on my Mac ( OS 14.8 Sonoma). I had a lot of subfolders into which I had put incoming and sent emails on particular topics. For example I had a folder called Family, and inside that I had a subfolder called Birthdays as well as many other family related topics.  My last Time Machine back up is about a month ago but that would be good enough to restore from.  I tried âImportâ in Thunderbird but it only imported the main folders and the emails within but not the subfolders.  I have another email address besides the deleted one and if I overwrite the whole Profile with the older one from Time Machine it will lose a lot of new stuff accumulated since that backup.  Any help most appreciated </blockquote> <p>Can you just add the add the account back into Thunderbird?  Once you have an account you can point the account to the correct folder which you say explicitly that you did not opt to delete when you removed the account.  Problem solved without extra tools or trying to merge data that has not been removed back in somehow.  The can be done in account settings &gt; Server settings by changing the account directory to the correct one. </p><p>I assume you have now realized that all of an account data hangs off the account so removing it removes the agility to access the data for the account.  As you point out it does not remove the data, just you ability to access it. Sometimes I wish these folder trees still had the joining lines on them so folk would realize that the stuff is connected and where. </p>",

              :content => "<em><p>Ruth Nicholls <a href=\"#answer-1795447\" rel=\"nofollow\">said</a></p></em> <blockquote>There must be some way to get the emails back. </blockquote> <p>Open your Thunderbird profile folder, then quit the Thunderbird application. In the profile folder open the folder Mail, identify and open the \"pop.xxx.yy\" account folder which should still contain the messages of your deleted POP account. Copy the mailbox files (without suffixe) such as Inbox, Sent, Drafts, Archives  ... to <strong>Local Folders</strong> which are also located in the Mail folder. If you see file folders such as Inbox.sbd, Archives.sbd, ... also copy them to Local Folders. You may have created personal folders in the old POP account such as Business, Vacations, Family, ... Copy them to Local Folders, too.  Don't bother about the .msf files. When you restart TB you should see folders and messages of your deleted account in Local Folders in the folder pane. </p> <em><p>Ruth Nicholls <a href=\"#answer-1795447\" rel=\"nofollow\">said</a></p></em> <blockquote> Maybe I will have to use the whole Profile from the last Time Machine backup. The old stuff is more important to me than the latest. </blockquote> <p>If you use your profile in the Time Machine backup from one month ago with the still existing POP account you will also import the \"specific reason\" for which you have already deleted it once! Then it would be easier to follow Matt's proposal to add the account back in Thunderbird and point it to the corresponding old account folder in Mail. </p>",

The file folder \"Family.sbd\" contains the mailbox files \"School\" and \"Robert\" corresponding to the subfolders with same name.  So you'll have to copy/move both - <strong>Family.sbd</strong> folder and <strong>Family</strong> file -  to preserve folder hierarchy and message content. </p>",

                   :id => 1797574,
          :question_id => 1561552,

              :updated => "2026-02-01 12:13:28 -0800",
              :content => "<em><p>Ruth Nicholls <a href=\"#answer-1797443\" rel=\"nofollow\">said</a></p></em> <blockquote> While this was happening, I asked my original question on this forum, which you have solved for me. But I have now ended up with a mess, and many duplicated folders, many of which are not complete, do not have all/any of the emails or the subfolders. I think the best way to show you is for me to do some screenshots.  So there are 5, in sequence, showing the whole left-hand column in TB from top to bottom , with a small amount of overlap for continuity. If you have the time to look at this you will see what a mess and how much duplication there is. </blockquote> <p>Undeniably this is a big mess but actually you are the only person to sort out this mess since you have created all those thematic \"archive\" folders in Local Folders. You know what they contain and where they belong in the folder hierarchy. No helper in this forum can do this for without sitting before your screen, opening all folders and subfolders to verify their contents and to compare with other folders or sub-folders having the same name but perhaps not the same message contents.  </p> <em><p>Ruth Nicholls <a href=\"#answer-1797443\" rel=\"nofollow\">said</a></p></em> <blockquote> So I need to be able to compare them, side by side on the same screen, to cross check. I hope you understand. So, my question is, what can I do about this other than to compare one folder with the same one from a different bit of the tree? I can get two TB folders to open together in two adjacent windows, and make comparisons, and then am I right that if I delete from one side the other side will not be changed? not be deleted?</blockquote> <p>You can open two folders having the same name in two different Thunderbird windows side by side by R-clicking on the folder name &gt; \"Open in a New Window\", then compare their messages in the thread panes. And you can copy selected messages from one folder to the other (see image). I'd prefer \"copy\" to \"move\" to avoid moving to wrong folders and then missing them in the original folder. When both folders have identical messages, you can delete one of them.  </p> <em><p>Ruth Nicholls <a href=\"#answer-1797443\" rel=\"nofollow\">said</a></p></em> <blockquote> Is there a better way to do this?  </blockquote> <p>I only know the manual way I just proposed.  </p> <em><p>Ruth Nicholls <a href=\"#answer-1797443\" rel=\"nofollow\">said</a></p></em> <blockquote>  Eventually, when I get rid of the duplication I want to also remove one of the gmail accounts, as they are the same email address and all incoming emails go to both. So is it better to try to preserve the original POP account, or go with the IMAP one? I think I have to make this decision before starting to remove duplicates. I confess I don't know what the difference is and which is better. (I have an iPhone and gmail works well on that with the app and through Apple Mail). </blockquote> <p>Difficult question. Some people get better along with POP accounts than with IMAP, often because they began emailing with with POP accounts. Eventually, when both your gmail POP account and your gmail IMAP account have the same folders with the same messages contents, you could delete one of them. But since you also use this gmail address on your iPhone with Apple Mail it might be better to keep the IMAP account in Thunderbird in order to synchronise messages between Thunderbird and iPhone. </p>",

    [0] {
                   :id => 1795561,
          :question_id => 1561623,
              :created => "2026-01-22 09:12:53 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-22 09:12:53 -0800",
              :content => "<p>Taking the right actions to ensure that all your messages are in Thunderbird (e.g., set for off-line use) may be sufficient (I don't know), but then Thunderbird would keep trying to connect to that account after it was deleted, so you would want to move the messages to local folders later anyway. </p><p>The best thing to do is to to copy all the server folders to your local folders account. You can even select the folders and copy them all in one step to the local folders account. Very easy. </p><p>Back up your profile first. </p><p>You'll have to decide when to do that and how to monitor for new messages that must be copied to local folders too. Or you could create a message filter that moves all new messages to a local folder so you don't have to monitor. </p><p>When you're done, back up your profile again. </p><p>I know IMAP pretty well. I don't know much about gmail. One thing to consider with gmail is the allmail folder. You'll want to make sure that you have a good understanding of what is in it before doing anything with it. </p>",
              :creator => "mozilla98",
              :is_spam => "false",

    [1] {
                   :id => 1795693,
          :question_id => 1561623,
              :created => "2026-01-22 16:59:50 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-22 16:59:50 -0800",
              :content => "<p>Thank you Rick for your time and input! </p><p>Just to be sure we are talking about the same things. </p><p>When you say \"copy all the server folders to your local folders account\" you mean download all emails to my hard disk? </p>",
              :creator => "psoe",
              :is_spam => "false",
          :num_helpful => 0,
        :num_unhelpful => 0
    },
    [2] {
                   :id => 1795700,
          :question_id => 1561623,
              :created => "2026-01-22 19:15:26 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-22 19:15:26 -0800",
              :content => "<em><p>psoe <a href=\"#answer-1795693\" rel=\"nofollow\">said</a></p></em> <blockquote>When you say \"copy all the server folders to your local folders account\" you mean download all emails to my hard disk? </blockquote> <p>No. Thunderbird has an account called \"local folders\" for storing messages only on the computer. Other accounts (server accounts, e.g., gmail) store messages both on a server and on the computer. IMAP keeps them in sync. You want 1) to ensure that all the messages in your server account are downloaded from the server to the computer, then 2) copy them to folders in the local folders account. Then those messages wil be on the computer no matter what happens to the server account (gmail). </p><p>To do 1, which you asked about: Go to account settings &gt; synchronization &amp; storage and check \"Keep messages in all folders for this account...\" Then click \"Advanced\" and select all folders. I don't know if that second step is redundant. </p><p>This next step may also be redundant, but I would check the settings just to be sure: For each folder with messages that you want to preserve, right click on the folder, select \"Properties\", go to the \"General information\" tab and check \"when getting messages for this account ...\", then to go the \"Synchronization\" tab, and check \"Select this folder for offline use\", then \"download now\". </p><p>To do 2: After that, copying folders from a server account to the local folders account is easy. All the folders that you want can even be copied in one step. You can shift-click or control-click or command-click to select multilple folders. Then right click on them, select \"copy to\", and copy them to the local folders account. Copying is quick. I tested this process earlier today and copied 2,000 messages in a few seconds. </p><p>You should back up your profile before you do anything and after you do everything. </p><p>If you copy folders now while the gmail account is still active, you will have to decide what to do about new messages arriving in your gmail account that are not in your local folders. One approach would be to create a message filter to copy them automatically to a local folder. Then your local folders will be current at all times. Oh, you would also have to create a filter to copy sent messages. Or you could wait until right before the gmail account is disabled before copying your folders to the local folders account. </p><p>Allmail: you may know that it holds all messages, including those in trash. Your messages have other gmail labels that show up in Thunderbird as folders. If you subscribe to allmail, you will have duplicates of all your messages. A common recommendation ion the forum is not to subscribe to allmail in Thunderbird because of the duplicates. </p><p>I don't use gmail and I am not an expert on it, but I believe that those statements are true and helpful. </p><p>Keep asking. </p>",
              :creator => "mozilla98",
              :is_spam => "false",
          :num_helpful => 0,
        :num_unhelpful => 0
    },

Any hint to make that happen?  </blockquote> <p>Create a new folder in Local Folders for the inbox (named something else), select all the messages in your gmail inbox, right click, and copy them to that new folder. </p> <blockquote>I am still unsure whether or not all emails got already copied downloaded. How to ensure it before copy the folders from Gmail acc to local folders acc? </blockquote> <p>Monitor the status bar at the bottom of the window. If you don't see it, View menu &gt; Toolbars &gt; Status bar. The activity manager helps too. Tools &gt; Activity manager. If you have set all the settings that I suggested, and you have gotten all new messages (File menu or button in the folder pane header, and the status bar is not reporting activity, and the activity manager reports that the account is up to date, you can probably feel confident that you got all the messages. </p>",

So I would check those things first. If you change the search term a little, say, use only the first name instead of first and last name, do you get results? If you search for something else, do you get results? </p><p>If there's evidence that search is just not working properly, one remedy is to re-build the global database. Instructions are here: <a href=\"https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/rebuilding-global-database\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/rebuilding-global-database</a> </p><p>I have no experience re-building the global database.               :content => "<p>If you used the tools&gt;export feature to move the profile, all passwords are removed for security. I always suggest using the OS's file copy facility to achieve that when passwords are to be retained: Here are sample steps: </p> <ol><li> click help&gt;troubleshootinginformation </li><li> scroll to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder' </li><li> exit thunderbird - IMPORTANT </li><li> you are now in the profile folder. copy ALL of it and save to external media  </li><li> install thunderbird on new PC, if not already done </li><li> click help&gt;troubleshootinginformation </li><li> scroll to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder'  </li><li> exit thunderbird  </li><li> you are in the profile. Paste what you copied here   ######## </li><li> restart thunderbird </li></ol>",

You can use you address book to filter mail  That is the only way anything can begin to know what is a legitimate known sender. </p><p>Have you considered using the existing delete settings for account to have deleted mail removed immediately without moving to the trash.  Personally I shudder to think of the mess I could create without the option to recover my mistakes.  But it does meet your requirement of not having mail in the trash. After all it is garbage and no one really needs to keep their garbage around for any length of time. </p><p>Something I am seeing more and more of is folk wanting a bespoke assistant to manage their digital affairs  that understands how they personally think and can anticipate what they might or might not want to see.  My wife does a pretty good job of that,  but she is probably the only one that knows me well enough.  Thunderbird certainly does not have a personal assistant.  Perhaps you should suggest it. </p>",

              :content => "<p>I think you have misunderstood my problem/position/request. Rather thoroughly. </p><p>BECAUSE TB makes mistakes, and a deleted mistake CANNOT be recovered, is precisely why I don't allow TB's automatic filtering to delete *anything*. </p><p>But I have my own list. And if you (not you personally, but I'm sure you understand what I mean) are on it, I don't, without any exception, want to see or recover your mail.  Particularly, I don't want to see it in Trash, as one of so many potential spam messages (maybe 100 at a time) that the volume requires me to painstakingly go through the entire list to see if a mistake has been made. </p><p>If TB would filter MY list first, and DELETE anything in that list, immediately, those deletions would NEVER have mistakes. Because they would be on my KNOWN spam list. But it does not. It puts them in Trash, with, on rare occasion, a mistake. </p><p>I want TB to filter MY LIST as mail arrives, and delete ONLY what I specify. But DELETE those, not move them to trash. My filter would catch about 95%+ of all the spam. It would not make mistakes. So instead of having to sort through, say, 100 mails in the Trash to look for TB mistakes, I would have to sort through maybe 5. Clearly, this would be an enormous improvement. </p><p>No, I'm not, of course, going to let TB delete anything based on it's OWN rules. But on MY rules, I want deletion to occur. </p><p>I don't want to SEE those mails that I specify. </p>",

              :is_spam => "false",
          :num_helpful => 0,

(Changing my email is not a good option at all.)  </p><p>But I can (and actually have made) filter those repeat messages. These are KNOWN, and known-to-be, 100% garbage. </p><p>And I don't want to sort through them to ensure that a rare TB auto-filtering mistake has occurred. There are emails I know, from NAMES (the spammers have defeated address filtering for the most part via random character generation that precedes a valid domain that one DARE NOT list). If that NAME is in the From, it's garbage. I don't want to see it. Not ever. There should be an incoming filter that deletes those. </p><p>The other suggestion, was probably unnecessary.                    :id => 1796083,
          :question_id => 1562082,
              :created => "2026-01-24 18:27:19 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-24 18:27:19 -0800",
              :content => "<p>You can't always get what you want. One click? Not that I know of. But three clicks, yes. </p><p>- Use your infallible filter rule to first tag the messages it catches with a custom tag; then delete them. The filter will execute every time Thunderbird gets New Mail. </p><p>- Create a separate rule that will Delete only messages with your custom tag. This rule can be manually run (Tools | Run Filters on Folder) against the Trash folder as often as you wish. This will forever delete them from this universe but leave all other messages in Trash;  </p><p>1. One click to select the Trash folder; </p><p>2. One click to choose menu item Tools; </p><p>3. One click to choose Run Filters on Folder </p><p>or key combination Alt - T - R to execute steps 2 and 3. </p>",

But it has to be in one or the other.  </p><p>They could defeat this by making everything random generated. But then there is no human-readable hook. </p><p>I filter the hooks. </p><p>I just want TB to delete ONLY what I filter, and nothing else. Its adaptive filter can fill my Trash. But three clicks, yes.  - Use your infallible filter rule to first tag the messages it catches with a custom tag; then delete them. The filter will execute every time Thunderbird gets New Mail.  - Create a separate rule that will Delete only messages with your custom tag. This rule can be manually run (Tools | Run Filters on Folder) against the Trash folder as often as you wish. This will forever delete them from this universe but leave all other messages in Trash;   1. One click to select the Trash folder;  2. One click to choose menu item Tools;  3. One click to choose Run Filters on Folder  or key combination Alt - T - R to execute steps 2 and 3. </blockquote> <p><br> It's kind of what I'm doing, but without tagging.                :id => 1796078,
      :question_id => 1562082,
          :created => "2026-01-24 16:26:55 -0800",
          :updated => "2026-01-24 16:26:55 -0800",
          :content => "<p>I think you have misunderstood my problem/position/request. Rather thoroughly. </p><p>BECAUSE TB makes mistakes, and a deleted mistake CANNOT be recovered, is precisely why I don't allow TB's automatic filtering to delete *anything*. </p><p>But I have my own list. And if you (not you personally, but I'm sure you understand what I mean) are on it, I don't, without any exception, want to see or recover your mail.  Particularly, I don't want to see it in Trash, as one of so many potential spam messages (maybe 100 at a time) that the volume requires me to painstakingly go through the entire list to see if a mistake has been made. </p><p>If TB would filter MY list first, and DELETE anything in that list, immediately, those deletions would NEVER have mistakes. Because they would be on my KNOWN spam list. But it does not. It puts them in Trash, with, on rare occasion, a mistake. </p><p>I want TB to filter MY LIST as mail arrives, and delete ONLY what I specify. But DELETE those, not move them to trash. My filter would catch about 95%+ of all the spam. It would not make mistakes. So instead of having to sort through, say, 100 mails in the Trash to look for TB mistakes, I would have to sort through maybe 5. Clearly, this would be an enormous improvement. </p><p>No, I'm not, of course, going to let TB delete anything based on it's OWN rules. But on MY rules, I want deletion to occur. </p><p>I don't want to SEE those mails that I specify. </p>",
          :creator => "yukitaga",
          :is_spam => "false",
      :num_helpful => 0,
    :num_unhelpful => 0
} is from original_poster

I just can't get TB to get them out of the way as they come in, which should not be a problem. Remember, these are MY rules, not TB's \"learning function\". These are KNOWN, and known-to-be, 100% garbage. </p><p>And I don't want to sort through them to ensure that a rare TB auto-filtering mistake has occurred. There are emails I know, from NAMES (the spammers have defeated address filtering for the most part via random character generation that precedes a valid domain that one DARE NOT list). If that NAME is in the From, it's garbage. I don't want to see it. Not ever. There should be an incoming filter that deletes those. </p><p>The other suggestion, was probably unnecessary.           :content => "<em><p>Lin <a href=\"#answer-1796083\" rel=\"nofollow\">said</a></p></em> <blockquote>You can't always get what you want. One click? Not that I know of. But three clicks, yes.  - Use your infallible filter rule to first tag the messages it catches with a custom tag; then delete them. The filter will execute every time Thunderbird gets New Mail.  - Create a separate rule that will Delete only messages with your custom tag. This rule can be manually run (Tools | Run Filters on Folder) against the Trash folder as often as you wish. This will forever delete them from this universe but leave all other messages in Trash;   1. One click to select the Trash folder;  2. One click to choose menu item Tools;  3. One click to choose Run Filters on Folder  or key combination Alt - T - R to execute steps 2 and 3. </blockquote> <p><br> It's kind of what I'm doing, but without tagging. I just have to open the Trash, then open the filter, then run it. </p><p>Why can't this be automated? </p>",

This will be your template </li><li> open that export into a spreadsheet program </li><li> note the top row. this shows the columns as thunderbird expects them to be </li><li> open your exported outlook csv into spreadsheet and adjust columns to match, including the top row.  </li><li> save as csv </li><li> import into thunderbird </li></ol>",

It is however not the list Thunderbird generated.  It is also undertaken on Windows 11 so if there is a bug  it would have to be in the field list or the operating system. </p><p>Please post any bug link here as this is one of my areas of interest.  </p><p>Did your import mess up the locations of the data it imported?  or just proceeded as suggested in the source comment below successfully. </p><p>I see this comment in the import source. <a href=\"https://searchfox.org/comm-central/source/mailnews/import/modules/AddrBookFileImporter.sys.mjs\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://searchfox.org/comm-central/source/mailnews/import/modules/AddrBookFileImporter.sys.mjs</a> starting at line 87 </p><pre>/**   * Parse a CSV/TSV file to an array of rows, each row is an array of columns.   * The first row is expected to contain field names. If we recognize all the   * field names, return an empty array, which means everything is parsed fine.   * Otherwise, return all the rows.   *   * @param {nsIFile} sourceFile - The source file to import from.   * @returns {string[][]}   */ </pre> <p>I would therefore assume you have not encountered a bug in the non display of the field selector as the names export by Thunderbird should parse without issue. </p><p>I did try and export from outlook and the CSV file was as I sort of expected, garbage.  But it is technically a CSV file.  Like everything Microsoft they did not tell a lie.   </p><p>Apart from exporting 66 fields of mostly blank information.  It did not follow any real process of quoting text I could see,  some things were, others were not.  All over the place.  </p><p>The unenclosed empty text fields and the general mismash of quoting was enough to trip up the Thunderbird CSV parser into placing the entire first record into the title field.  So we are dealing with garbage out, garbage in almost certainly.  I would suggest you make the failure to just ignore the unenclosed empty fields or strip the quotes as LibreCalc did  the focus of your bug report.  LibreOffice calc was not fooled and managed a successful import the text.  Saving the data in LibreCalc out as CSV made for a successful import in Thunderbird.  No editing in LibreCalc required, but the field associations were off and needed correction. </p>",
              :creator => "MattAuSupport",
              :is_spam => "false",
          :num_helpful => 0,
        :num_unhelpful => 0

              :content => "<p>If you have a new Thunderbird installation and set up a POP account, in the beginning you won't see a Sent folder. By default Thunderbird only creates an Inbox and a Trash folder after set up of POP accounts.  A Sent folder will be created when you send the first message from your account. Idem for other folders such as Drafts, Archives, Templates. </p><p>Ã¬f you have an IMAP account it might be necessary to R-click on the account name &gt; Subscribe .... and check the Sent folder in the folder list. </p><p>Whether a Sent folder is displayed or not in the folder pane may also depend on which folder view is activated: go to View &gt; Folders &gt; .... </p>",

D, [2026-02-11T23:30:28.642850 #80361] DEBUG -- : q:{:question_id=>"1562243", :original_poster=>"ceciljohn6"}
D, [2026-02-11T23:30:28.643722 #80361] DEBUG -- : matching_answers: [
    [0] {
                   :id => 1796277,
          :question_id => 1562243,
              :created => "2026-01-25 17:09:51 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-25 17:10:48 -0800",
              :content => "<em><p>John Howard <a href=\"#question-1562243\" rel=\"nofollow\">said</a></p></em> <blockquote>I didn't know I had a Mozilla account.  Should I create one?  Download Firefox? </blockquote> <p>Well you have posted here,  so you clearly have such an account as posting requires it. </p><p>See  <a href=\"https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/user/ceciljohn6/\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/user/ceciljohn6/</a> </p><p>Personally I would suggest you try using Firefox.  I have a deep distrust of Both Microsoft and Google when it comes to my browsing habits.  Both make millions from personalized adds.  Mozilla makes essentially nothing from selling my browsing habits because they do not do it. </p> <blockquote> I've relied on my Thunderbird e-mail program for decades.  When my Google password changes it is always tricky to get Thunderbird to talk to Gmail.  But I don't ever remember being asked for a primary password again.  Looking through the \"articles\", I'm not sure they are talking about e-mail or web browsers. \"The imap server <a href=\"http://imap.gmail.com\" rel=\"nofollow\">imap.gmail.com</a> does not support the selected authentication method.  Please change the authentication method.\"  I am using OAuth2 as my authentication method.  I tried entering my Google password early Saturday and it started receiving mail again.  I was ecstatic.  But it didn't last!  It broke down again.  Please help.  I've donated a lot of money to Thunderbird. </blockquote> <p>Your donations are not in anyway relevant to support, undoubtedly appreciated by the development arm of things. But my efforts are freely given.  I am a volunteer and so is almost everyone that puts in an appearance in this forum. </p><p>There is essentially only one authentication method that can be used for Gmail,  that is oAuth  Your confusion regarding browsers and such is somewhat understandable as oauth is really a browser authentication method that Google have forced into use everywhere.  Fortunately Thunderbird is built on the same foundation as Firefox, so like a chameleon when required it can run with the need to be a browser and display browser pages,  which it does for the google oauth authentication flow. </p><p>For the Authentication process to work,  you must have cookies enabled in Thunderbird (yes it is a thing and is enabled by default)  the process also requires JavaScript to be enabled in Thunderbird.  This is all discussed here  <a href=\"https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/automatic-conversion-google-mail-accounts-oauth20\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/automatic-conversion-google-mail-accounts-oauth20</a> </p><p>When you use oAuth authentication Thunderbird never actually knows your password,  nor does it know the two factor authentication key that you may also be asked to insert that was texted or email to you.  Those pages are webpages served by Google and the posted responses go back to them. Only at the end does Thunderbird get a token from google which it uses to authenticate going forward.  While the token is stored in Thunderbird password manager,  you will never be asked for it.  This is an entirely automated process and storing the token in an encrypted form as if it was a passord lread to it being stored as one. </p><p>Most folk have issues with Gmail authentication because of their choices regarding passwords and security software.  The use of VPNs is becoming widespread,  but nothing is more likely to see your authentication with gmail requiring a reset that the VPN.  At a very simple level Google know where you phone is (I am sure their hacking detection algorithm is actually very complex, not simple.  But for this discussion simple will suffice).  Then you start connecting Thunderbird from somewhere else entirely.  That raises a red flag about you being hacked, your token is revoked and Thunderbird asks for a re-authentication. </p><p>Changing you password in Google should not affect Thunderbird as it is not using your google password.  Google might ask for a re-authentication by revoking Thunderbird token,  but there should be nothing inherently tricky about it.  Unless you have an antivirus that is blocking aspects of the process.  Unfortunately the only windows antivirus I am aware of that is not subject to regular issue is Microsoft/Windows  Defender. </p>",
              :creator => "MattAuSupport",
              :is_spam => "false",
          :num_helpful => 0,
        :num_unhelpful => 0
    }
]

This is the Support Forum, so you have come to the right place. </p><p>You need to provide the crash report id. If you selected to 'add a crash report' it may have auto gone through, but I need to find it. You will not get any response from thunderbird developers.  </p><p>So when you start Thunderbird the first thing you need to do is find that crash ID. </p><p>Look in Thunderbird </p> <ul><li> Help &gt; Troubleshooting Information </li><li> Scroll down to 'Crash Reports for the last 3 days' section </li><li> There should be a Crash report ID which just looks like a bunch of letters and numbers and should start with a bp. </li><li> Just copy that crash ID and paste it into this forum. </li></ul> <p>If there is nothing then check the following is selected. </p> <ul><li> Settings &gt; Privacy &amp; Security </li><li> scroll down to Thunderbird Data Collection and Use </li><li> Select 'Allow Thunderbird to send backlogged crash reports on your behalf. </li></ul>",

D, [2026-02-11T23:30:28.668812 #80361] DEBUG -- : matching_answers: [
    [0] {
                   :id => 1796531,
          :question_id => 1562420,
              :created => "2026-01-27 03:57:11 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-27 03:57:11 -0800",
              :content => "<p>I am unclear on you situation. If you have a newer PC, you can transfer 100% from the old to the new with these steps:  </p> <ol><li> start thunderbird on old PC </li><li> click tools&gt;export and then click 'open profile folder'  </li><li> exit thunderbird </li><li> copy profile content to external media </li><li> install thunderbird on new pc, downloaded from <a href=\"http://thunderbird.net\" rel=\"nofollow\">thunderbird.net</a> </li><li> in receiving PC, click help&gt;troubleshootinginformation </li><li> scroll to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder'  </li><li> exit thunderbird  </li><li> now, paste contents of exported profile, overlaying contents of profile.  </li><li> if there is a compatibilitie.ini file, delete it </li><li> restart thunder </li></ol> <p>if The old PC was a POP account and you just want to copy some of the messages to a different PC, that is also possible. Please clarify you intent. Thanks </p>",
              :creator => "davidsk",
              :is_spam => "false",

              :content => "<p>- CD or thunbdrive, whichever works for you. THumbdrives are just simpler. You are to exit thunderbird to ensure that thunderbird has released control of all the files. Otherwise, you might find the copied profile is incomplete. Yes, as I state in step 8, exit thunderbird prior to pasting the new profile. As a visual reminder, what is happening is that, when you step 2 and step 8, you will have both Thunderbird open and Windows File Explorer open. By exiting thunderbird, all you will be left with is file explorer. In going through the steps, it becomes obvious.  The profile copes everything, absolutely everything. When you restart on new PC after pasting in the profile, you should see everything there, all folders, all accounts, and the complete addressbook, plus all of your settings. </p>",

              :content => "<p>I think the last 3 entries in your first picture are incorrect.  On my setup, the gmail account corresponds to N = 5, and these are two of the preferences: </p><p>mail.server.server5.hostname has the value <a href=\"http://imap.gmail.com\" rel=\"nofollow\">imap.gmail.com</a> </p><p>mail.server.server5.authMethod has the value 10 (for OAuth2) </p><p>Each of your accounts corresponds to a different N = 1,2,3,... </p><p>I also have mail.smtpserver.smtp3.hostname with the value <a href=\"http://smtp.gmail.com\" rel=\"nofollow\">smtp.gmail.com</a> and </p><p>mail.smtpserver.smtp3.authMethod with the value 10 </p><p>Yes, it seems complex, but the vast majority of users don't need to do this.  You have to match the accounts with the correct prefs in order to set the authentication method. </p><p>Uninstalling and reinstalling the program is unnecessary in this case as the user data (profile) is separate from the program folder. </p>",
              :creator => "sfhowes",
              :is_spam => "false",

I believe that workspace accounts use the same servers as consumer accounts, i.e. <a href=\"http://imap.gmail.com\" rel=\"nofollow\">imap.gmail.com</a>, 993, SSL/TLS, OAuth2; <a href=\"http://smtp.gmail.com\" rel=\"nofollow\">smtp.gmail.com</a>, 465, SSL/TLS, OAuth2. When you import the csv, do you see a prompt that shows the columns available and how to match? Please see attached screenshot.               :updated => "2026-01-27 13:51:25 -0800",
              :content => "<p>First, although profile names have no specific function, do NOT rename them casually. That is because the thunderbird startup profile expects the same name as the last time. Just leave alone. The best you can do is to not have an unworkable system. Technically, you could rename the profile 'charlie' or 'suzie' and it would work just the same. but thunderbird has to know that's the name before it starts. </p><p>YES, thunderbird uses just one profile. you can safely delete all others from the ...appdata\\roaming\\thunderbird\\profiles folder. I did that, as it was just wasted space. </p>",
              :creator => "davidsk",
              :is_spam => "false",

D, [2026-02-11T23:30:28.681317 #80361] DEBUG -- : matching_answers: [
    [0] {
                   :id => 1796623,
          :question_id => 1562491,
              :created => "2026-01-27 10:21:34 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-27 10:21:34 -0800",
              :content => "<p>I'm not clear about what your intent is. If you want to extract addresses from all the messages in a local folder and add them to an address book that can then be exported to a CSV file, it can be done with the aid of the alternative address book, \"Cardbook\". </p><p><a href=\"https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/cardbook/\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/cardbook/</a> </p><p>- Create a new local Cardbook address book </p><p>- Create a Message Filter for Local Folders like shown in the attached image, where the criteria is \"Age is greater than 0 days\" (to select all messages in the foler); action is \"Add From to Cardbook\" (you can also choose To, CC, and BCC addresses).  </p><p>- Select the local folder in question and run the filter against it. </p><p>The receiving Cardbook Address Book will have all addresses, including duplicates, so it may need some grooming. Cardbook includes a de-dupe tool. </p><p>I expect there are other ways to do this, and you may not want to install Cardbook for just this operation. Since I already use Cardbook, this is how I'd do it. </p><p>If this isn't your goal, please clarify. </p>",
              :creator => "rednoise",
              :is_spam => "false",
          :num_helpful => 0,
        :num_unhelpful => 0

    [0] {

              :content => "<p>Probabilmente nella tua rubrica hai associato il nome di questo mittente all'indirizzo di un provider PEC. Dovrebbe bastare cancellare il mittente dalla rubrica: </p> <blockquote>La PEC nel sistema italiano Ã¨ una particolare email con valore legale. Per ottenere questo risultato la comunicazione tra un mittente MITT ed un destinatario DEST Ã¨ mediata dal una societÃ  abilitata alla gestione della PEC rispondente a precisi requisiti tecnici (GEST). Nelle intestazioni della PEC avremo quindi riferimenti a MITT, DEST e GEST.  Supponiamo che DEST, ricevuta una PEC da MITT, voglia aggiungere il mittente alla propria rubrica di Thunderbird. A volte capita che al nome di MITT non vanga associato il relativo indirizzo email ma quello dell'intermediario GEST. Il risultato Ã¨ che da quel momento in poi tutte le PEC ricevute da utenti di GEST appariranno con mittente MIT, talvolta con la dicitura \"per conto di\".  Per risolvere il problema Ã¨ necessario cancellare il contatto MITT dalla rubrica.</blockquote>",
              :creator => "@next",
              :is_spam => "false",
          :num_helpful => 0,
        :num_unhelpful => 0
    }
]

    [0] {

              :content => "<ol><li> first, you need to do a backup. I presume the profile is at c:\\&lt;yourid&gt;\\appdata\\roaming\\thunderbird   You can verify that by clicking help&gt;troubleshootinginformation, scrolling to 'profile folder' and clicking 'open folder'. I place sample backup unstructions further down in this post </li><li> down latest thunderbird from <a href=\"https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/</a>   Select the ESR version 140. That is updated annually.  </li><li> uninstall the beta. if prompted about data records, select to leave them.   </li><li> now install the ESR release. If there are issues, post back on this thread for assistance. As soon as possible, click settings&gt;general and set the update feature to advise but NOT to automatically install updates. I recommend that, as you are using Thunderbird as a business and will want to control software updates.   </li></ol> <p>Sample backup steps are below:  <em>BACKUP'</em> </p> <ol><li> ensure thunderbird is not running </li><li> enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key </li><li> this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\\roaming folder </li><li> highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media or to a separate folder  </li></ol> <p>Whether this resolves your issue, I have no idea. My presumption is that your tax software is desiged to work with current releases of email software. Good luck to you in resolving this. </p>",

D, [2026-02-11T23:30:28.729781 #80361] DEBUG -- : q:{:question_id=>"1562948", :original_poster=>"scida1"}
D, [2026-02-11T23:30:28.730573 #80361] DEBUG -- : matching_answers: [
    [0] {
                   :id => 1797149,
          :question_id => 1562948,
              :created => "2026-01-29 18:38:48 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-29 18:38:48 -0800",
              :content => "<p>No, there is not. There is the sneaky system used by spammers as well as \"legitimate\" senders that embed a link in an HTML-formatted message to an external image, often just one invisible pixel. Retrieving this image, sometimes called a \"web beacon\" will alert a monitoring server somewhere that can tell the sender that the recipient has opened the email... *IF* the recipient is set up to automatically display external images. The average sender wouldn't usually have a way to monitor this - it requires access to a web server.  </p><p>Thunderbird (and virtually all other) email clients have a setting to disable auto image display, and I would encourage everyone to do so. You can enable auto-download for trusted senders if you want, but I would still discourage it. Safer to do it manually. </p><p>In other words, yes, there is at least that method, but it's easily defeated, which pretty much makes it uselessly unreliable. </p>",
              :creator => "rednoise",
              :is_spam => "false",
          :num_helpful => 0,
        :num_unhelpful => 0
    }
]
D, [2026-02-11T23:30:28.730590 #80361] DEBUG -- : q:{:question_id=>"1562956", :original_poster=>"hoges52.mh1"}

D, [2026-02-11T23:30:28.739581 #80361] DEBUG -- : q:{:question_id=>"1563063", :original_poster=>"noh.spam"}
D, [2026-02-11T23:30:28.740440 #80361] DEBUG -- : matching_answers: [
    [0] {
                   :id => 1797329,
          :question_id => 1563063,
              :created => "2026-01-30 17:29:55 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-30 17:29:55 -0800",
              :content => "<em><p>noh.spam <a href=\"#question-1563063\" rel=\"nofollow\">said</a></p></em> <blockquote>It seems to me that the account settings in Thunderbird 140.6.0esr (64-bit) have changed,  </blockquote> <p>Nope </p> <blockquote>because without any supporting documentation in 'help' I can no longer see a way to enter a password.  </blockquote> <p>See <a href=\"https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/password-manager-remember-delete-change-tb\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/password-manager-remember-delete-change-tb</a> which you will note has not been edited since September last year and that was a <a href=\"https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/password-manager-remember-delete-change-tb/compare?locale=en-US&amp;to=304895&amp;from=263648\" rel=\"nofollow\">minor edit.</a> </p><p>The current version is expanded from my original blog post in 2011 <a href=\"https://thunderbirdtweaks.blogspot.com/2011/07/pssswords.html\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://thunderbirdtweaks.blogspot.com/2011/07/pssswords.html</a> with the addition of an option to edit a saved password.  But I can not see there ever being a need to allow the user to enter a password there. </p><p>So you are looking for something that has really never existed.  Thunderbird will ask you for a password if it needs one and offer to save it.   </p><p>However just setting the authentication method to password does not guarantee you will be asked if you have other software on your system that consumes the connection attempt so the server never requests a password. Common causes of failures to request passwords are things like antivirus products and in your case they are also blocking access to <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Localhost\" rel=\"nofollow\">localhost </a> and the odd proxy type port numbers that Proton uses. </p><p>Port 1143 appears to be registered for use by informix to exchange data. See <a href=\"https://www.infomatrix.ro/\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://www.infomatrix.ro/</a> and <a href=\"https://isc.sans.edu/data/port/1143\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://isc.sans.edu/data/port/1143</a>    Port 1025 is often used as an alternative SMTP port,  but it has a past in the Windows RPC and the associated vulnerabilities and patches over the years so a problematic choice on most occasions. See <a href=\"https://www.pentestpad.com/port-exploit/port-1025-microsoft-rpc-microsoft-remote-procedure-call\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://www.pentestpad.com/port-exploit/port-1025-microsoft-rpc-microsoft-remote-procedure-call</a> </p> <blockquote> I have two gmail accounts which are working but I also have a Protonmail account which has stopped working. The Protonmail Bridge show the following details for entry in the Thunderbird client's account settings:  <strong>IMAP</strong>: Hostname (127.0.0.1), Port(1143), Username(withheld), Password(withheld), Security (STARTTLS)  <strong>SMTP</strong>: Hostname (127.0.0.1), Port(1025), Username(withheld), Password(withheld), Security (STARTTLS)  I can enter the following:  Hostname, (127.0.0.1), Port(1025), Username(withheld), Connection Security(STARTTLS) &amp; Authentication method (normal password) but nowhere to enter the actual password! </blockquote> <p>You enter it when you are asked for it.  Always have.  Thunderbird does ask you to enter it when you are first creating an account,  simply to reduce the number of password requests as there may be many attempts to connect to the mail server in the setup process attempting to detect the servers settings. </p> <blockquote> How do I do this and where in the docs is this described, please  Thanks </blockquote> <p>As you appear to be using Linux in one of the X11 version I will guess it is probably a Ubuntu derived distribution and will be using SNAP packages with their special sandbox built in.  How that works with  those ports,  I have no idea.  But many folk have issues with the SNAP versions and permissions and have reverted to DEB packages which just work. </p><p>Ubuntu derived distributions will also most likely have the Ports 1025 and 1143 closed. While the definition of localhost says that the transmission should never go to a physical adaptor,  I could see it being bundled with the general software firewall rules.  So have you checked your software firewall?  Have you checked your installed version of Thunderbird has access to those ports through the snap sandbox.  </p><p>Do you have development environments or server software like Apache installed that may by consuming port 1025 connections or even things like mailpit or mailcatcher? </p>",
              :creator => "MattAuSupport",
              :is_spam => "false",
          :num_helpful => 0,
        :num_unhelpful => 0
    },

              :content => "<em><p>noh.spam <a href=\"#answer-1797451\" rel=\"nofollow\">said</a></p></em> <blockquote>I'm sure I'm not going mad/senile. I remember entering my Protonmail password!? Also Wayland/OpenSuSE  Could my partial configuration of Nginx/LetsEncrypt/PiHole have a bearing? </blockquote> <p>As I said before when you configure your account initially you are asked for your password.  Also as I said you were asked for it and if it is needed again, or if the saved password is unsuccessful in making a connection, you will be asked for it again.  After that it is saved and you can access that from the password manager. </p><p>Why are you using encrypted communications on your own hardware?  the data travels nowhere,  but you are adding the overhead of encrypting the communications between two software items on your local machine.  I am sure an argument can be made that it makes the interception of the communication harder,  but in all honesty Thunderbird stores your mail as plain text,  so it is some weird transitory level of security.  However you will need to add an exception to the certificate in the certificate manager is you want to use it,  or use a trusted certificate issuing authority to sign your certificates. </p><p>But you are at point 4 or 5 in the Proton setup  <a href=\"https://proton.me/support/protonmail-bridge-clients-windows-thunderbird\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://proton.me/support/protonmail-bridge-clients-windows-thunderbird</a>  </p><p>The dialog is different but the root cause is largely the same.  Use the certificate manager to ad an exception for the server. (search cert in settings) </p>",

              :created => "2026-01-31 04:15:18 -0800",
              :updated => "2026-01-31 04:15:18 -0800",
              :content => "<p>Thunderbird itself does not use AI. Moreover, Thunderbird is a local email application, meaning it installs and runs as a client on your device. It does not provide email addresses, nor the service to transmit emails. But Thunderbird can be used with your existing email address and service provider to send, receive, sort and search your email messages. </p><p>Wrt your concern about Gmail and AI, this is completely unrelated to the email client you use to access your Gmail account. It is of course up to you not to use Gmail as your email provider if you feel uncomfortable about what they are doing.  For standard, free users, Google maintains that they do not train Gemini or other large language models on your email content. Features like Smart Compose or Automatic Tab Sorting do \"read\" your emails to work, but Google clarified that these are localized processes. Turning them on does not grant Google the right to use your emails for AI training. If you explicitly use Gemini Extensions (where you ask the AI to \"find the receipt in my Gmail\"), the specific prompts you type and the resulting interactions may be used to improve the service, but the rest of your inbox remains private. </p><p>Note, every email provider is scanning your messages for malware, a.k.a. they are all 'reading' your email anyway. </p>",
              :creator => "christ1",
              :is_spam => "false",
          :num_helpful => 0,
        :num_unhelpful => 0
    }

              :content => "<p>My guess is that thunderbird created a new profile and that the addressbook is there, but in another profile. My assumption is that Thunderbird was already installed and that you were updating to a newer version. Try this: - click help&gt;troubleshootinginformation - scroll down to 'profiles' and click 'about:profiles' - if there is more than one profile showing, click 'open folder' on the inactive one - now, the addressbook's name is  abook.sqlite. do you see one there, that may have been updated recently? If so, that may be your missing addressbook. If so, then copy the abook.sqlite and history.sqlite files  to a separate folder (This is temporary) - now, close windows file manager and you are back in thunderbird at the list of profiles. Now, click 'open folder' for the active profile, then EXIT THUNDERBIRD, now, paste the two copied addressbooks here, overlaying the current files.  - now, restart thunderbird and your addressbook should be there. </p>",

              :content => "<p>First, this is a peer-to-peer forum. I, and other volunteers, are just that, users the same as you. I will ignore your vulgarity and attempt to give a useful response. To be clear, you are NOT clear in explaining your issue. Is this same email being returned to the inbox, or is more email coming to you from the same sender? If it's the latter, Thunderbird is doing what its documentation says; it uses a Bayesian filter as documented here::  </p><pre><a href=\"https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-junk-spam-messages\" rel=\"nofollow\">https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-junk-spam-messages</a>   What that means is that Thunderbird evaluates each incoming message on its own merits. Translation for you: thunderbird does not have a black list; just because you mark a message as spam does not guarantee that future messages will be marked as spam. If you want thunderbird to be more active, you have an obligation, also documented, to train thunderbird by identifying regularly both spam and non-spam. With that, I end my response. I leave it to others to deal with your vocabulary. </pre>",
